Add support for Content-Disposition via stash options

Merge pull request #1 from kaoru/test-improvements

CPAN Pull Request Challenge - Very small test improvements!

Add support for Content-Disposition via stash options

Setting $c->stash->{excel_disposition} to a string will set that for the
Content-Disposition header. The default is "inline".

Setting $c->stash->{excel_filename} will set the filename appropriately
in the Content-Disposition header. The default is "excel.xls".

issue.title: User needs to enable "Addon bar" to see the switch!
issue.body:
User needs to enable "Add-on bar" to see the switch!

To turn on the "Add-on bar", the user needs to press Alt then click View, mouse-over Toolbars, and check "Add-on bar". (also, there is a short cut: Ctrl + /)

Please put the switch some-place else or make the "Add-on bar" appear automatically.

issue.title: Bug with FF 4.0
issue.body:
I noticed that it often does not remember the cache toggle setting.

It is green (on) when i close FF 4 and when i start firefox again then it is often turned off (red), i can switch it back on again, as long FF is not turned off it stays green but as soon as FF is closed and restart it is turned off again.

I only can fix it by removing it completely and reinstall it again, then it works normal again, it keeps working for a while and then spontaneously it is default off again. 

This happened several times already , I am using FF 4.0 on win7(x64) and cache toggle version 0.6.

Is there a fix/update to be accepted what would fix this?

issue.title: Increase Accessibility
issue.body:
This really nice Add-on displays the information just through color alone. Hard to see which state it has if you suffer from a red-green weakness (like me ;). My suggestion is to put two little icons (I/O) in the background of the slider like in iOS (iPad). Perhaps the color also could be adjusted.

Furthermore you could add a title to your Add-on which appears on mouseover (useful if the label is turned off).

If you're interested in a fork/patch I could try it, but I have to warn you, I never edited FF-Addons before ;)

example for #dbg:
first line; //#dbg

second line;//#dbg
third line;

fourth line;//#dbg

namespace has disappeared elsewhere; disappear it here so xmltk works.

Discussed on IRC, irc.perl.org#moose.

Merge pull request #3 from three18ti/master

Updated xmltk documentation per your recommendation.
fixed spelling
updated documentation for xmltk utility
lots of cleanups before release, including checking we don't break CPAN
fix the metaclass incompat bugs reported in #perl-help
kill extraneous use of aliased

have git ignore local::lib directory

* Fix missing dep on MooseX::App::Cmd spotted by mateu
* Fix bad synopsis code spotted by mateu

update changes bump version number
add back the XML::Toolkit::App as a stub/wrapper around the config

reset state between Loader parse calls so we can re-use the loader
try fixing namespaces a bit
add CDATA support
add (failing) test for CDATA

Several small changes

* Add README.md (back?)
* add lib/XML/Toolkit/Config/Container.pm (back?)
* modify XML::Filter::Moose and it's descendants to use MooseX::NonMoose and
  clean up the inline_constructor => 0 stuff
tidy README.md some
fix the spacing in README.md
add README.md
fix a bug in the generate command
update PerlMongers XML example
clean out the legacy namespace attribute
kill Loader::FilterNS by merging it into the main Filter
add dep on Test::Exception we added to the tests
port commandline scripts across to the new Bread::Board
remove MooseX::Autobox dep
convert Generator over
merge Loader across
move Builder over to using Bread::Board
add missing dep to Makefile.PL
silence warning
update for 0.08 release
merge immutable branch
clean up XSPF example
update example
add TODO test for RDF
forgot some diagnostics in a test
clean up POD, examples, and tests
update RNG example
add updated XML::AIML
kill old xmltk_make_classes
clean up the basic test
fix up tests before release
remove the YP oriented tests cause *stevan* thought they were a bad idea. (He is right)
clean up the XML namespaces for yp-api.t

build a new example based on XSPF

going through and building a new example using the XSPF file for a
client, I had to perform some cleanup of how generate and the
templates work.

The templates have been unified into XML::Toolkit;:Cmd::ClassTemplate
with the generate command wrapping it with the logic to break stuff out.
This cleans up some nastiness and makes the templates more uniform.

we're also adding a test for XSPF round tripping.

fix to run with the current Moose and MooseX::MetaDescription

Moose 0.94 introduced some changes to the way Attributes are handled in
Roles. As a side effect the Attribute inheritance no longer works in
Role -> Role composition. We copy the Attribute now until this is fixed
in Moose.

Also patch a few tests to deal with the changes that have happened in
the codebase that we didn't detect before.

* add test for yp-api

We needed to have RDF support for the YP Feed API. This adds a test that slurps the current version of the API XML so we can round-trip it.

* get the XML tests passing

The `namespace_map` for the Generator has to be different from the ones for the Loader and Builder. We fix the test for this, fix the code to reflect the changes, and everything magically works.

* clean up the logic from the unresolve_namespaces flow

change the logic (and wording) to "unless no_unresolved_namespaces" rather than "if unresovled_namespaces" since we're checking if the list "is_empty"

remove the need for MooseX::AttributeHelpers

MX::AH was folded into core. This removes all of the places we use
MX::AH I think in both the processing code, and the generated code.

clean up generated code and tests

The Generated code was using MooseX::AttributeHelpers which has been
folded into core. We fix that to use Native::Attribute's now. We also
move to use nammespace::clean.

We also start moving the tests to use `done_testing` instead of no_plan.

Finally we fix the Filter to properly add the XML trait to text nodes as
well as non-text ones, this squishes some warnings.

fix add_text_attribute to include 'XML::Toolkit::MetaDescription::Trait'

We need to be sure that the generated classes have the right
meta-description trait. We were getting a warning for the text
attributes when generating them, this should fix that.
start migrating from MXAH to Moose::Attribute::Native
fix the moose drift

comments.body: Hey, it is your choice if you want some of the CPANTesters to lose their jobs!

issue.title: Port the majority to Moo
issue.body: So other than the actual class building (which requires metaclasses) everything else (the loading/serializing logic mostly) can use Moo. We should migrate stuff to Moo so that people who don't want to buy Moose for those bits don't have to.

issue.title: Bootstrap RelaxNG
issue.body: It should be possible to bootstrap RELAXNG from  http://www.relaxng.org/spec-20011203.html#IDA5MCS

issue.title: Bootstrap XML-Schema
issue.body: XML-Schema has a meta-schema at http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema.xsd this hopefully should enable us to bootstrap parsing XSD files.

Added an HTML5 version of the default templates set.

When creating a new Hyde site, this new default_html5 templates set can be used to start from an HTML5-compatible baseline, in lieu of Hyde's standard default which uses XHTML 1.1 (see the respective versions of layout/skeleton/_base.html).  In terms of files and directory structure, I followed the Hyde default, plus cleaned up some inconsistencies in syntax.

Added two new methods to ContentNode class: walk_child_pages, and walk_child_pages_by_updated, which help generate (sorted, level-ized) lists of Pages to be used with table-of-contents and chronologically-ordered site-map-like web pages. Apply commit c5d58798 and provide date format customization

Regarding category management the commit c5d58798 from my branch myfork did some changes mandatory to make rss generator working.

It is now possible also to customize the date format inside rss feeds (must be RFC 822 compatible). The default is %d %b %y %H:%M GMT.

Enhance RSS support

The post processor Rss2FeedGenerator now supports description, uuid, author and pubDate elements in a better way. Customisation and parametrisation still need to be added.

Merges CategoriesManager and CategoriesArchiveGenerator.

CategoriesArchiveGenerator was dependant on the CategoriesManager. There are now merged in one pre processor.

Allow the {% markdown %} tag to use extensions.

This will allow you to use extensions with python-markdown. For example:

    {% markdown toc %}
        [TOC]

        # My Project

        ## Design

        ... text ...

        ## Implementation

        ... text ...
    {% endmarkdown %}

The standard {% markdown %} tag (without any extensions) is unchanged.

comments.body: The problem here is that, YAMLContentProcessor(which is what I am using) returns a date time and PyContentProcessor returns a string. I guess its time to completely retire the PyContentProcessor.
I forgot to test it with a YAMLContentProcessor.  Did my patch break that?  Maybe the function should test whether page.created is a string or a datetime.
Yes. I have a patch - still testing it.

Oh, forgot to ask: Are you using / would like to use PyContentProcessor(python dictionaries instead of YAML)?

With my website I found that using YAML was so much better (No quotes needed etc)
I find YAML to be much easier to use than Python dictionaries in this context.
Cool :) You hit the final nail on the PyContentProcessor Coffin.

While this change seems to have fixed the issue where Hyde would crash when Unicode characters were used in templates, the characters appear strange when output to the html.  

I tried using the registered trademark symbol and it appears as "".
Did you provide the appropriate content-type? This should do it:
That fixed the problem.  Thanks.
Excellent idea! I have to test that this weekend.
Its pretty cool - now I wonder how I worked without this :). There is still some work left on identifying and notifying about errors, but this is a good first step.

IMHO setting markdown extensions right into the templates is not the best solution. I added for example the management of footnotes on my hyde fork. If I want to add by default the footnote management -- with the current solution -- I would need to add a markdown tag with footnote as parameter to set it as extension. A better option, as I implemented at first, is to set extension inside the settings.py file. At least it is a better option for me but in the end the best may be to include both solutions.

What do you think?
I agree. Will add it in.
Both options should work, because there are times when you might only want an extension active on one particular block.

issue.title: /prerendered/hyde-icon.png causes error
issue.body:
I installed successfully hyde, init a default template `-t default`, and i encountered with:

```
INFO:Processing /prerendered/hyde-icon.png[2013-11-18 21:26:12,088]
***********************
Error while rendering page /prerendered/hyde-icon.png
***********************
Generation Failed
Traceback
...
...
UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf8' codec can't decode byte 0x89 in position 0: invalid start byte

```

And solved simply by removing hyde-icon.png, i think hyde supposes this file as a content and tries to render as a text.

issue.title: Jinja2 is parsing CSS & chokes on valid syntax
issue.body:
This took a long time to figure out

I was getting this error for some reason: 

```
~/path > hyde gen -r
 22:27:10 hyde.engine Reading site configuration from [/path/site.yaml]
 22:27:10 hyde Regenerating the site...
 22:27:10 hyde.engine Reading site contents
 22:27:10 hyde.engine Generating site at [/path]
 22:27:10 hyde.engine Configuring the template environment
 22:27:10 hyde.engine Reading site contents
{'index_file_names': ['index.html'], 'append_slash': False, 'strip_extensions': ['html']}
 22:27:10 hyde.engine Generating site to [/path/deploy]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/hyde", line 8, in <module>
    load_entry_point('hyde==0.8', 'console_scripts', 'hyde')()
  File "/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/hyde-0.8-py2.6.egg/EGG-INFO/scripts/main.py", line 10, in main
    Engine().run()
  File "build/bdist.macosx-10.6-universal/egg/commando.py", line 198, in run
  File "/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/hyde-0.8-py2.6.egg/hyde/engine.py", line 90, in gen
    gen.generate_all(incremental=incremental)
  File "/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/hyde-0.8-py2.6.egg/hyde/generator.py", line 198, in generate_all
    self.__generate_node__(self.site.content, incremental)
  File "/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/hyde-0.8-py2.6.egg/hyde/generator.py", line 289, in __generate_node__
    self.__generate_resource__(resource, incremental)
  File "/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/hyde-0.8-py2.6.egg/hyde/generator.py", line 302, in __generate_resource__
    self.update_deps(resource)
  File "/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/hyde-0.8-py2.6.egg/hyde/generator.py", line 144, in update_deps
    deps.extend(self.template.get_dependencies(rel_path))
  File "/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/hyde-0.8-py2.6.egg/hyde/ext/templates/jinja.py", line 592, in get_dependencies
    ast = self.env.parse(text)
  File "/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/Jinja2-2.5.5-py2.6.egg/jinja2/environment.py", line 393, in parse
    self.handle_exception(exc_info, source_hint=source)
  File "<unknown>", line 1, in template
jinja2.exceptions.TemplateSyntaxError: Missing end of comment tag
```

Turns out, a recent change I made caused my compiled CSS files (I am not compiling using Hyde mechanisms currently, FWIW) to contain the string `{#`.  Jinja2 freaked out because it thought it was the beginning of a comment.

The above is perfectly valid syntax in CSS; after all, if you are minifying your CSS and it contains an `@media` section that starts with an ID-based selector, then wham: `@media something{#foo{...}}`. And you wont be able to `hyde gen -r` anymore.

Note that my CSS is within the `content/media/css` directory.

issue.title: Files in the content dir that start with and '_' should not be processed at all
issue.body:
As far as I understood files in the content dir that start with an underscore are supposed to be complelety ignored. In fact they won't be copied to the deploy folder. However, when adding hyde attributes to an underscore-prefixed file they _are_ processed wich is not intuitive.

Here's an example:

`_template.html`

```
{% extends "_post.html" %}
{%hyde
    title: Title
    created: 2010-01-01
    updated: 2010-01-01
    categories: [dummy1, dummy2]
    tags: []
%}
{% block excerpt %}

Put here the excerpt / introduction. This is going to be included in the real
post, too.

{% endblock %}
{% block article %}

Put here the main content

{% endblock %}
```

When using the category manager it lists the categories _dummy1_ and _dummy2_. Although you can easily circumvent the issue by omitting any categories in `_template.html` it is probably conceptionally cleaner if underscore-prefixed files would be totally ignored.

issue.title: Feature request: Faster site generation by compiling only modified source files
issue.body: If the generator kept a list of compiled files, and only processed new and newer-modified files, the generation time after any small modification to the source files would be greatly reduced.

issue.title: Site is not generated under Windows
issue.body:
Steps to reproduce:
1) python hyde.py -i -s c:\mysite
2) python hyde.py -g s c:\mysite
Infinite loop starts and process never ends

I fixed it changing hardcoded slashes to os.sep in url.py:
return (parent.rstrip("/") + os.sep + child.lstrip("/")).rstrip("/")
and 
url = url.strip(os.sep)

issue.title: render_excerpt fails (inc patch)
issue.body:
The following issue:

```
INFO:Processing /blog/[2010-02-21 22:09:24,468]
***********************
Error while rendering page /blog/
***********************
Generation Failed
(<type 'exceptions.AttributeError'>, AttributeError("'SafeUnicode' object has no attribute 'render'",), <traceback object at 0x1013c9f38>)
```

Was fixed with the following patch:
    diff --git a/hydeengine/templatetags/hydetags.py b/hydeengine/templatetags/hydetags.py
    index aec60ed..88a33e4 100644
    --- a/hydeengine/templatetags/hydetags.py
    +++ b/hydeengine/templatetags/hydetags.py
    @@ -39,7 +39,7 @@ def excerpt(parser, token):
         return BracketNode("Excerpt", nodelist)    

```
 @register.tag(name="article")
-def excerpt(parser, token):
+def article(parser, token):
     nodelist = parser.parse(('endarticle',))
     parser.delete_first_token()
     return BracketNode("Article", nodelist)
@@ -63,8 +63,6 @@ class LatestExcerptNode(template.Node):

     def render(self, context):
         sitemap_node = None
-        if not self.words == 50:
-            self.words = self.words.render(context)
         self.path = self.path.render(context).strip('"')
         sitemap_node = context["site"].find_node(Folder(self.path))
         if not sitemap_node:
@@ -154,7 +152,7 @@ def latest_excerpt(parser, token):
     if len(tokens) > 1:
         path = Template(tokens[1])
     if len(tokens) > 2:
-        words = Template(tokens[2])
+        words = int(tokens[2])
     return LatestExcerptNode(path, words)

 @register.tag(name="render_excerpt")    
@@ -165,7 +163,7 @@ def render_excerpt(parser, token):
     if len(tokens) > 1:
         path = parser.compile_filter(tokens[1])
     if len(tokens) > 2:
-        words = Template(tokens[2])
+        words = int(tokens[2])
     return RenderExcerptNode(path, words)

 @register.tag(name="render_article")    
@@ -182,8 +180,6 @@ class RenderExcerptNode(template.Node):
         self.words = words

     def render(self, context):
-        if not self.words == 50:
-            self.words = self.words.render(context)
         page = self.page.resolve(context)
         context["excerpt_url"] = page.url
         context["excerpt_title"] = page.title
```

issue.title: Markdown Extension Documentation
issue.body: Markdown extensions add a fair bit of complexity and must be documented in the wiki.

issue.title: IncludeTextNode assumes markdown
issue.body: The IncludeTextNode template tag assumes that markdown library as opposed to markdown2 library is used. It also does not factor in the Markdown extension settings.

issue.title: Categories Manager will overwrite context['categories'] with the last processed node.
issue.body: The line `context['categories'] = categories` assumes that the pre-processor will run for only one node. It should check if there are categories defined in the context already and merge if needed.

issue.title: issue with hyde tags <!-- Hyde::...::Begin--> and restructured text (and possibly textile and asciidoc)
issue.body:
**restructuredtext** does not recognise _html_ statement and treat them like text. you have to include them in a raw paragraph like that: 
.. raw:: html
so that there are outputted like html. so this cause problem when you use _restructuredtex_t and you have **{% article %}** or **{%excerpt %}** tag in the middle of a **{% restructuredtext %}** block because all the html comment HYDE tag are rendered in html. For example: 
{% block article %}
{% restructuredtext %}
{% article %}
{% excerpt %}
This is a test
{% endexcerpt %}
This should show how article and excerpt (django) tags normally rendered in html comment are shown in plain html while inside restructuredtext block
{% endarticle %}
{% endrestructuredtext %}
{% endblock article %}
is rendered in html as : ```

<!-- Hyde::Article::Begin -->

<!-- Hyde::Excerpt::Begin -->

This is a test <!-- Hyde::Excerpt::End --> This should show how article and excerpt (django) tags normally rendered in html comment are shown in plain html while inside restructuredtext block <!-- Hyde::Article::End -->

``` one have to use **{% restruturedtext %}** block at lowest level possible and use article and excerpt blocks on the outer level of restructured text block. i guess that the same problem could be find with **textitle** and **asciidoc** if they can't recognize html statement and do treat them like text.

issue.body:
hi. i just used the **default** template, and from the code of _content/blog/blog.html_ and __listing.html_ and __innerlisting.html_, i expect to see some **excerpts** in _deploy/blog/blog.html_ once i run _./hyde.py -g_ but there is none. in fact, if i look at _layout/skeleton/_innerlisting.html_, this seems wrong 
{% if page.excerpt %}
    {% render_excerpt list_page %}
{%endif%}
shouldn't it be {% if list_page.excerpt %} ? but this does not work either. in fact list_page does not seems to have excerpt_title or excerpt_url either. niether page. the only way to make it work is to simple remove the if test keeping only 
{% render_excerpt list_page %}
and this, at last, works as expected. However, by looking at _hydeengine/templatetags/hydetags.py_, i have easily spotted an error: line 170: 
@register.tag(name="render_article")

should be

def render_article(parser, token):
but this does not seems to cause problem at all...

issue.title: issue with yuicompressor and clevercss
issue.body:
hi. i was trying to use a clevercss template in media/css and after ./hyde.py -g, i noticed only a .ccss and a .ccss.z-tmp in my deploy/media/css it seems the command running the yuicompressor failed because the file deploy/media/css/base.ccss.z-tmp contains: 
Usage: java -jar yuicompressor-x.y.z.jar [options] [input file]

Global Options
  -h, --help                Displays this information
  --type            Specifies the type of the input file
  --charset        Read the input file using 
  --line-break      Insert a line break after the specified column number
  -v, --verbose             Display informational messages and warnings
  -o                  Place the output into . Defaults to stdout.

JavaScript Options
  --nomunge                 Minify only, do not obfuscate
  --preserve-semi           Preserve all semicolons
  --disable-optimizations   Disable all micro optimizations

If no input file is specified, it defaults to stdin. In this case, the 'type'
option is required. Otherwise, the 'type' option is required only if the input
file extension is neither 'js' nor 'css'.
it seems to fail because the input file has .ccss extension one need to use --type css if the extension is not .css there seems to be an issue with the pipe processing of media processor. base.ccss is converted to base.ccss by clevercss (wouldn't it be better to be base.css), then yuicompressor use base.ccss but fails because the extension is not .js or .css. also, if i remove the yuicompressor from the pipe for ccss in my settings.py, i end up with a base.ccss in my deploy/media/css, that file containing css and not clevercss, **and then should have been called base.css**.

issue.title: Feature Request: Git-style CLI + plugin interface
issue.body:
I'd like Hyde to take Git/webgen style commands as well, e.g. `hyde.py init` and `hyde.py serve`. 

This could also be a beginning of a plugin system - `hyde.py foo` could try to run a script called `foo.py` in a `plugins` directory inside the main Hyde directory.

issue.title: Add support for related items
issue.body: Essentially this would mean adding support for Categories/Tags. Can be integrated as a part of hyde by directly supporting Categories property on `Page` and a method for retrieving related pages in `SiteNode` or as a content processor.

issue.title: Paths with spaces silently fail when using YUI Compressor (Mac OS X)
issue.body:
If the path to the file to be compressed contains a space on Mac OS X, the YUI compressor step silently fails because the shell can't accept spaces in paths.

Replacing line 61 in media_processors.py with the code below fixes this, but there's surely a more graceful way to do this (additionally, the problem will affect any other command-line arguments used by Hyde, like those for HSS, and this step might not be necessary for all OSes or shells; I don't know much beyond bash, myself).

```
u"java -jar %s %s > %s" % (compress.replace(' ', '\ '), 
    resource.source_file.path.replace(' ', '\ '),
    tmp_file.path.replace(' ', '\ ')
))
```

At the very minimum, Hyde should print an error to the command line when generating a site that has spaces in its path to let the user know that YUI has failed to compress the file and why.

issue.title: Execution of TemplateProcessor as ordinary CONTENT_PROCESSOR
issue.body:
If I understood the code of processor.py correctly, TemplateProcessor.process(resource) is executed explicitly for all documents in the content/-tree. I think it is more logical not to do so, but to add TemplateProcessor to the default CONTENT_PROCESSOR list.

This would e.g. enable you to limit TemplateProcessing to specific file extensions or subfolders of the content/-directory.

What do you think?

issue.title: YAML
issue.body:
I like what you're doing here. Always thought the backtrace could be made more useful. It occurs to me that it can be hard to decide what exactly one should show in a backtrace, you never know what the developer wants to see, and providing everything can be an overload. That led to to think it would be cool if the backtrace did provide everything, but in YAML, and then we could pipe that to a filter command to see it in different ways, even write our own filters. name: shellac
description: Shellac provides protection to Java programs through a hybrid of dynamic checking and static analysis.

commit.message: added || to the proof obligations for if statements
We can now use instance variables in requirements.
initial commit of tokeneer example
updated readme

Added basic support for history and better object copying.

A requirement variable can store a discrete history of its values, to be used in the checks.
The checker can use the ReqVar name, with [] appended to it.
This currently has a limitation that requirement variable names must be unique, even across theorems.

Annotated variables can now be any primitive type, or any object that has a copy constructor, as long
as that copy constructor performs a deep copy. Also, it can be an array of any of the other supported types.
Some common types, like Integer are not currently supported, so the corresponding primitive types
should be used.

Topological sorting for ambiguous types

Types are sorted topologically now. All variants in a single slot are
tried for a match, and if the result is ambiguous an error is thrown.

This matches Perl 6's behavior for multi method dispatch.

issue.title: Update to_xls.rb
issue.body: Numeric lets you use Float and Integer.

issue.title: Excel 2007 "Extension Hardening" warning: '#{filename}', is in a different format than specified by the file extension
issue.body:
When trying to use the output of this (or other straight XML manually built), Excel 2007 will give the following warning:

```
"The file you are trying to open, '#{filename}', is in a different format than specified by the file extension. Verify that the file is not corrupted and is from a trusted source before opening the file. Do you want to open the file now?"
```

I've tried renaming to .xlsx, but it gives this error and refuses to open at all:

```
"Excel cannot open the file #{filename} because the file format or file extension is not valid. Verify that the file has not been corrupted and that the file extension matches the format of the file."
```

It's probably denying to open it since .xlsx files are .zip's with lots of xml files, e.g.:
    $ unzip new.xlsx # file saved straight from Excel
    Archive:  new.xlsx
      inflating: [Content_Types].xml  
      inflating: _rels/.rels  
      inflating: xl/_rels/workbook.xml.rels  
      inflating: xl/workbook.xml  
      inflating: xl/sharedStrings.xml  
      inflating: xl/styles.xml  
      inflating: xl/theme/theme1.xml  
      inflating: xl/worksheets/sheet1.xml  
      inflating: docProps/core.xml  
      inflating: docProps/app.xml        

I've also tried some other alternate MIME types, without luck.

Some more details are available at http://www.grinn.net/blog/dev/2008/06/file-you-are-trying-to-open-is-in.html
This is apparently due to extension hardening, and the fact that the strategy used by this plugin doesn't seem to be "true xlsx": http://blogs.msdn.com/vsofficedeveloper/pages/Excel-2007-Extension-Warning.aspx

issue.title: Prune / Clarify existing Date Modules
issue.body:
See also #23 

Following discussion on #toolchain, its not clear that any of `Date::Tiny` `DateTime::Tiny` or `Time::Tiny` are actually very useful, given they're all into this "floating timezone" stuff, but profoundly, have "now" methods that assume local timezone ..... 

Its also really not clear how Date::Tiny and DateTime::Tiny differ, if at all.

And DateTime should have some kind of warning label on its usage, because any amount of sophisticated usage is going to want to do date math with it,.... and then roll into the fun problem where DateTime objects are mutable and $date->add( otherdate ) mutates the date in place, so the only responsible use involves lots of $date->clone->add(.... ).

And hence, `DateTime::Moonpig` exists.

And that has its own issues that make it hard to use, like not being amenable to "fuzzy" increments ( ie: can't add 1 month to 2016-01-01 to get 2016-02-01 ), instead, preferring to deal in time units for incrementing..

```
perl -MDateTime::Moonpig -E 'DateTime::Moonpig->new( year => 2016, month => 1, day => 1 )->plus( months => 1 )' 
# Argument "months" isn't numeric in addition
perl -MDateTime::Moonpig -E 'DateTime::Moonpig->new( year => 2016, month => 1, day => 1 )->add( months => 1 )' 
# Do not mutate DateTime objects! (http://rjbs.manxome.org/rubric/entry/1929) at /home/kent/perl5/perlbrew/perls/5.24.0-RC5/lib/site_perl/5.24.0/DateTime/Moonpig.pm line 85.
    DateTime::Moonpig::__ANON__(DateTime::Moonpig=HASH(0x2844e58), DateTime::Duration=HASH(0x21c0800)) called at /home/kent/perl5/perlbrew/perls/5.24.0-RC5/lib/site_perl/5.24.0/x86_64-linux/DateTime.pm line 1688
    DateTime::add(DateTime::Moonpig=HASH(0x2844e58), "months", 1) called at -e line 1
```

Hey,

It would be nice if the docs had a section listing all the available `Task::Kensho::*` categories. Essentially a list like this, but with the one-two word descriptions: 
![kensho-list](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5747918/6636824/2cea4c84-c94a-11e4-9702-d928e99a1148.png)

Last night I was browsing the module, looking for anything recommended for RESTful communications, and it was tough figuring out what sections Kensho even covers. I ended up scrolling through a giant TOC:

![kensho](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5747918/6636878/83530110-c94a-11e4-966c-97a8b0fea77d.png)

I think a list of sections in the docs would be beneficial.

issue.title: Request: add MCE
issue.body:
From: Mario Roy marioeroy@gmail.com
Subject: Searching the string "parallel" at Task-Kensho produce no results

```
Greetings Karen,

Thank you for the list of modules at https://metacpan.org/pod/Task::Kensho.
The list is very informative.

I searched the page for "parallel" and nothing came up. May I suggest MCE
as a possible candidate. MCE was written to tackle parallelism on a box.
MCE *does not* compete with other modules, but instead complements in the
wild. By itself, MCE provides out of the box parallelism for map and grep.

use MCE::Map;
my @a = mce_map { "Please add MCE $_\n" } 0 .. 1_000_000;

use MCE::Grep;
my @b = mce_grep { $_ % 7 == 0 } 0 .. 100;

One line enables parallelism in Test-Perl-Critic.
https://github.com/Perl-Critic/Test-Perl-Critic/blob/master/lib/Test/Perl/Critic.pm#L104

David Farrell did a nice write up on MCE some time back.
http://perltricks.com/article/61/2014/1/21/Make-your-code-run-faster-with-Perl-s-secret-turbo-module

MCE is a chunking engine. It eats big files for breakfast :). Well,
chunking has the effect of reducing IPC behind the scene.

http://api.metacpan.org/source/MARIOROY/MCE-1.521/images/02_Bank_Model_Chunking.gif

Every chunk comes with an ID. So easy to have ordered output while running.
http://api.metacpan.org/source/MARIOROY/MCE-1.521/images/03_Bank_Model_Chunk_ID.gif

MCE allows natural cross-over function calling. Serialization is done
automatically.
http://api.metacpan.org/source/MARIOROY/MCE-1.521/images/08_Natural_Callback.gif

There is even bin/mce_grep to enable scientists to parse massive genome
files using the binary agrep or tre-agrep commands.
https://metacpan.org/source/MARIOROY/MCE-1.521/bin/mce_grep

The presentation by Gavin Carr takes MCE for a spin.
http://www.openfusion.net/talks/pwp/
http://www.openfusion.net/talks/pwp/#22   mce_grep
http://www.openfusion.net/talks/pwp/#20   mce_loop

For folks who like prime numbers, compare the 2 examples. MCE runs with
Perl not compiled with threads support.

https://metacpan.org/source/DANAJ/Math-Prime-Util-0.49/examples/fibprime-threads.pl
https://metacpan.org/source/DANAJ/Math-Prime-Util-0.49/examples/fibprime-mce.pl

MCE supports an input iterator (complement to Jeffrey Thalhammer). Notice
how the MCE code is much smaller. To use threads (not fork, one simply adds
use threads; at the top).

Well, am hoping to see MCE listed for parallelism. Please... Thank you.

Kind regards,
Mario

----

Hi again,

In other words, may MCE be added to the list of modules at
https://metacpan.org/pod/Task::Kensho for enabling parallelism? I
understand that this request may be rejected. Oh gosh, will feel bad if
that were to happen. Will feel like all the hours was worth it if it were
to be added.

It was no small feat to have MCE run on all environments including
Windows/Cygwin. I am embarrassed to say, but that was hard.

Scientists out in QATAR (are using MCE -- mainly benefiting from workers
persisting between row data.
http://qatar-weill.cornell.edu

Of all things, MCE is helping with parallelism hacking molecules.
https://metacpan.org/source/DEMIAN/HackaMol-0.00_21/examples/MCE/heavy_mvr.pl#L11

I even received a report from Greece stating MCE is used in a Windows
production environment only possible with MCE 1.516 and later releases.

Well, MCE is my humble 2 cents in helping folks enable parallelism in Perl.

Thank you.
Mario

----

Just realized that I need to monitor the perlmonks site and help out answer questions.

Splitting large array for threads.
http://www.perlmonks.org/?node_id=1089915

Look at MCE go, better yet enabling chunking, and furthermore direct processing of the input file.
http://www.perlmonks.org/?node_id=1110247

Several folks have asked for Ruby-MCE, Python-MCE, even Go-MCE. Perl is first to receive MCE.

Work done thus far in Ruby-MCE has helped me solved a rare bug in Perl-MCE on Windows. The bug existed for the longest time and spent countless hours on many occasions trying to reproduce it. The bug presented itself in Greece and finally able to reproduce it.

If I had the time, would love to re-write MCE. Add more features. The next item for Perl-MCE is mce_start sub { ... } based on MCE::Flow and to run in the background. Several mce_start may run, each with various workers, each massively parallel with full chunking support. Also have mce_await, mce_status, etc. I can do this. Will be awesome.

I'm not totally sure about Perl6 and whether it will have chunking abilities. So may need to write Perl6-MCE one day.

Thank you in advance for considering MCE as a parallel module for the list. I would do a pull request, but not sure under what section to place MCE under. Thus the reason for not sending. Will wait for a go before sending a pull request otherwise.

Do I add it after Module Development?

MCE: Parallel Processing

Many-Core Engine for Perl providing parallel processing capabilities

Cheer,
Mario

----

Hi all,

I am ok if MCE is not listed on https://metacpan.org/pod/Task::Kensho. I
have found peace and no longer think about it.

There was one thing remaining with MCE. That is, a massive update on the
documentation itself. MCE 1.522 was released today.

1.522 Thu Dec 25 16:00:00 EST 2014

[BUG FIXES]

* Applied fix to MCE->shutdown so that MCE Models do not err when
  receiving signal to terminate.

* Optimization for MCE->print, MCE->printf, MCE->say and MCE->sendto.
  This was calling fileno unnecessarily. MCE->print('STDERR', ...)
  is not supported. Do this instead; MCE->print(\*STDERR, ...)

[ENHANCEMENTS]

* Inserts the actual lib-path at the head of @INC in example files.
* Massive documentation updates throughout the entire distribution.
* Renamed barrier_sync.pl to sync.pl; scaling_pings.pl to ping.pl.
* Updated requires in META.yml, Makefile.PL and perl-MCE.spec.
* Updated comment in MCE::Queue test scripts.
* Updated the README file.

[NEW FEATURES]

* Added sampledb examples demonstrating DBI and SQLite with MCE.
* Added step_demo.pl to examples.


All 6 models are powerful in MCE. Look at MCE::Grep go below.
https://metacpan.org/pod/distribution/MCE/lib/MCE.pod#MCE-MODELS

A common scenario is grepping for pattern(s) inside a massive log file.
Notice how parallelism increases as complexity increases for the pattern.
Testing was done against a 300 MB file containing 250k lines.

use MCE::Grep <https://metacpan.org/pod/MCE::Grep>;

my @m; open my $LOG, "<", "/path/to/log/file" or die "$!\n";

@m = grep { /pattern/ } <$LOG>;                      ##  0.756 secs
@m = grep { /foobar|[2357][1468][9]/ } <$LOG>;       ## 24.681 secs

## Parallelism with mce_grep. This involves the manager process
## due to processing a file handle.

@m = mce_grep { /pattern/ } <$LOG>;                  ##  0.997 secs
@m = mce_grep { /foobar|[2357][1468][9]/ } <$LOG>;   ##  7.439 secs

## Even faster with mce_grep_f. Workers access the file directly
## with zero interaction from the manager process.

my $LOG = "/path/to/file";
@m = mce_grep_f { /pattern/ } $LOG;                  ##  0.112 secs
@m = mce_grep_f { /foobar|[2357][1468][9]/ } $LOG;   ##  6.840 secs


Merry Christmas !!!

Kind regards,
Mario


```

description: Attempting to simplify the distribution of standard dotfiles across multiple machines while still allowing for local customizations (think 'vim, emac, shell aliases')

Added/updated a couple plugins, updated aliases

* Updated to rails.vim v4.3 (for Rails3)

Reworked JSON request/reply flow

REQUEST:

{module: "M", action: "A", event: "E", data: D}

event is optional, when omited, E = "M:A" is used
data is optional
D is any json value

REPLY:

{event: "E-term", reply: R}

term is "ok" | "fail", but can also be other term
R is any json value

wimenu history option locks keyboard on empty menu

wimenu grabs all keyboard input and locks up the system when an empty
choice list is given to key_menu() and the -h and -n options are used.

This fixes the problem by forgoing the -h and -n options altogether: we
can perform our own (unlimited length) history handling in Ruby itself.

status barlet parameters as inst vars, not methods

This commit cleans up the pollution of the status barlet object:

* No special instance variables, like `@definition` and `@refresh`.

* No method-missing to access parameters in barlet definition hash.
  Instead, script parameters (prefixed with '@') are made available
  as instance variables for use by Ruby code in the definition hash.

* Only one special instance method `refresh()` to redraw the label.

replace d/s/network/vpn with generic network applet

You can instantiate the generic network applet multiple times:

  import:
    - display/status/network

  display:
    status:
      network:
        instances:
          - interface: eth0

          - interface: wlan0
            refresh: 30

          - interface: tun0
            refresh: 5

          # and so on ...

launch_terminal action: rescue encoding errors

If the currently focused client contains non-ASCII characters in its
title, then File.expand_path() raises an EncodingError saying it cannot
process the non-ASCII string.  Try forcing the title's native encoding.

clear action: support confirmation dialogs on exit

Some clients, like GVim, pop up a confirmation dialog upon termination
if the user still has unsaved work inside the client.  Instead of
blindly killing all clients until none remain, try closing all current
clients *once* and then let the user handle any child clients (such as
confirmation dialogs) they may spawn.

You can no longer pass-in a list of clients to show as choices in

index_menu: add history & reverse-index choices

Do not prefix the choices with indices.  Instead, reverse-index the
choices array based on what the user's choices was.  This allows a
non-linear menu to be displayed (e.g. history before actual choices).

key_menu: history must not add nonexistent choices

Previously entered choices from the history should not be shown in the
menu unless they also exist in the list of choices passed to key_menu().

Added a subdirectory for each keybinding.  Now
it's required to include control/keyboard/qwerty
for a minimal base configuration.  Additionally
some "submodules" such as swap can included with
control/keyboard/qwerty/swap.  This will include
control/keyboard/include/swap automatic to
reduce redundant code between keybindings.

It's possible to define generic files for all
keybindings, too.  For example swap_by_number can be
found at control/keyboard/generic/swap_by_number.

This files will not automatically included and need perhaps some
files in control/keyboard/../* to be included.  For example need
generic/arrange_by_number the file $KEYBINDING/arrange.

allow disabling auto-refresh of status bar applets

By setting the value of 'refresh' to nil, we pass nothing to the
Thread#sleep() method, thereby causing the refresh thread to sleep
forever.  Status#refresh() will continue to work just as before.

make 'display:status' a Ruby 1.9 hash; closes GH-7

Ruby 1.9 is now required to use this wmiirc
because its hashes retains the insertion order of
their members and reflect it during iteration.

Without this new Ruby feature, we would need to go
back to representing 'display:status' as an array
of hashes; thereby losing the ability to address
and override things inside a particular status bar
applet.

comments.body: Nice applet. But battery.yaml and fbsd-battery.yaml are exactly the same file. (see http://github.com/sunaku/wmiirc/commit/65923f45286c2165fbf57d03ef1a28b5133edab8)
Thanks for telling me.  I just reverted that commit accordingly.
ifconfig are (usually) placed at /sbin/ifconfig which is (usually) not in user path -- perhaps /sbin/ifconfig should be used or a config flag for path
If another language is used this fails because addr is at my german system "Adresse". I using inet space to ignore inet6: /inet \s*(\S+)/

I'm using net-tools 1.60 -- ifconfig 1.42 (2001-04-13) and got following output for rx/tx:
RX bytes:19893350 (18.9 MiB)  TX bytes:3170010 (3.0 MiB)

this regex should match both versions: 
/(([.0-9]+\S+ \w*))/
Thanks for your suggestions nougad!  I pushed out a commit ed495dcb00995b36398d89e24767005b22755fbf implementing them.  Cheers.

YEAH! Unicode is really nice :)
But it fails if artist/song contains special character:
Encoding::CompatibilityError: incompatible character encodings: ASCII-8BIT and UTF-8
I suggest a .force_encoding("UTF-8") - works for me:
[artist.force_encoding("UTF-8"), title.force_encoding("UTF-8")]
Thanks nougad.  Fixed in cd740b1e0af14028e112cb072285673b62f827de commit.

```
require 'librmpd'
mpd = MPD.new
mpd.password "asdf"
```

results in an "RuntimeError: MPD: Not Connected to the Server"

you need to connect first and than using the password. So line 17 and 18 should be swapped.

Is there some other way to access a Status now? I really like the feature of a persistent notification bar but I don't know how to check if the button is created in notification or if it is my spacer barlet.
Thanks, fixed in a8136c4c4ed91e7315b135186b0a7f4d83171a60.

All actions defined in status bar applets have their IXP filename appended to the action names.  In addition, the first applet of its kind that is used also gets its personal actions aliased to the global space.  For example, if you have two volume applets, the first one gets two sets of actions: "decrease_volume" and "decrease_volume/rbar/1-1-volume".  The second one only gets one set of actions: "decrease_volume/rbar/1-2-volume".

You can check for any status bar applet existence with `fs.rbar["your_file"].exist?`.

Sorry, I don't get it. Accessing a applet with fs.rbar returns a Rumai::Node object. But the refresh method is defined in Status class. I don't know how to map the Node object to Status. As far as I understand rumai implements a Node and a Barlet inherits from Node. wmiirc inherits StatusBarlet and TagBarlet. And Status updates a StatusBarlet (btw why not implement die Logic in StatusBarlet?). So if I get the Rumai::Node Object it should be mapped (or it should be a method for manual mapping) to StatusBarlet/TagBarlet and even Status. But probably I missed something.
Understood.  Could you show me the code where you are trying to access a particular Status instance?  That would give me a better idea of how to approach this issue.  Thanks.

I try to reimplement the code you deleted in this commit. I want to delete the button only if is not in Status. Because I like the mouse actions (https://github.com/sunaku/wmiirc/blob/master/display/status/spacer.yaml) associated with "!notify". I changed the deleted line into following:

```
          if Rumai.fs.rbar["!notice"].exist?
            Rumai.fs.rbar["!notice"].refresh # doesn't work
          else
            button.remove
          end
```

The refresh doesn't work because the object has no refresh method. I get an Node object instead of the Status. But I have no idea how I can get the Status object to call the refresh method. I can't get Status["!notice"] anymore to call the refresh method.

Perhaps my idea is the wrong way. But beside of this I don't understand the reason for two classes. I expect the logic from Status in StatusBarlet and a class method:

```
def StatusBarlet#[](Rumai::Node n)
    return @@barlet_by_node[n]
end
```

So I would implement StatusBarlet[Rumai.fs.rbar["!notice"]].refresh

I converted the "notice" thing into a proper status barlet in ca2d807740c76c215efecf9561872f9215218a1a.  You can add additional functionality to it (such as your mouse-wheel to change views idea) from the comfort of your own `config.yaml` file:

``` yaml
display:
  status:
    notice:
      control:
        mouse_action:
          wheel_up: focus_next_view
          wheel_down: focus_previous_view
```
Yeah this is the right way. Thank you a lot!

I really like this commit! :heart: Seems like there is too much logic in some of the `.yaml` files. I believe it will be much easier if they were used almost strictly to `includes` or `key => value` config type to things. Similar to how the [Awesome Wicked library](http://awesome.naquadah.org/wiki/Wicked) does. Then users will be able to include their `.rb` files from their `~/.wmirc/`, `~/bin/`, or w/e...

The problem with this commit (and the reason why I dropped it) is that the Ruby logic isn't evaluated inside the same sandbox as the rest of the Ruby snippets in the YAML files are.  As a result, `lib/wmiirc/statusbar.rb` was unable to access the `Mouse` module defined by `control/mouse.yaml`.

Thanks for the pointer.  I'll read up on that library and consider your idea some more.

issue.title: Cooperative Multithreading
issue.body:
I measured battery usage with and without X and found a big difference (6W vs 11W). Of course my wmii config causes only a small part but I mentioned many wakeups by it. So I try a short profiling and see many time are consumed for all the thread stuff (synchronize, pass, etc). I thought about Cooperative Multithreading and want to know what you think about.

I would try it with two threads: One Thread waits that an event occurs and sleeps meanwhile. The other handles the status bar updates. This scheduler used a queue for update events (e.g two buttons A updates every 2 and B every 5 secs): | A | A | B | A | -- first sleep 2 secs, execute update method for A, sleep another 2 secs, call A, sleep one sec, call B, sleep one sec, call A. Of course some corrections required because update needs some time too.

I don't know if this effects any performance improvements but I give it a try. What do you think?

issue.title: modes for keybindings
issue.body:
Keybinding modes are basically a different set of keybindings for different tasks (e.g. no interference; client growing; client positioning; and other uses).  They should have a common escape sequence (like Control-Alt-Esc) which returns you to the normal keybindings.

Also add a status bar applet that shows the current keybinding mode.  You should be able to right-click it to see a menu of all modes (and switch to the clicked one).

issue.title: ability to save & load sessions
issue.body: Add the ability to save and load sessions to a YAML file.  A "session" action in the wmiirc can be used to script the loading of a default session on startup.

lib/Makefile.am: re2c compiling with bit vectors now.

lib/syck.c: clear parser on init. thanks, ts. [ruby-core:02931]

lib/token.re:
- using newline_len to handline CR-LFs.
  "\000" was showing up on folded blocks which
  stopped at EOF.

- buffer underflow. thanks, ts. [ruby-core:02929]

ext/ruby/lib/yaml/compat.rb: moved all ruby 1.6 -> ruby 1.8
  handling into compat.rb.

ext/ruby/lib/yaml/baseemitter.rb:
- simpler flow block code.

- was forcing a mod value of zero at times, which kept
  some blocks from getting indentation.

ext/ruby/lib/yaml/rubytypes.rb: exceptions were using an older
  YAML.object_maker. [ruby-core:03080]

ext/ruby/lib/yaml.rb:
- added YAML::load_file, YAML::parse_file.
- added rdoc to beginning of lib.

ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: set buffer after Data_Wrap_Struct to avoid possible GC.
  [ruby-talk:104835]

- lib/gram.y: added new scalar style, which reports whether a string
    comes in as a plain, block, single-, or double-quoted string.
- lib/syck.h: ditto.
- lib/token.re: ditto.
- lib/node.c: ditto.
- ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: symbols now only detected if the
    scalar is plain.  beginning of custom implicits!
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml*: fixes from Ruby CVS.
- lib/token.re: fixed escape sequences.
- lib/syck.h: version 0.44.

- ext/ruby/lib/yaml.rb: fixes for 1.6.8.
- lib/gram.y: transfers no longer open indentation.
- lib/token.rb: ditto. also, escape code fixes.

- lib/syck.c: fixed a problem with removed anchors gettin FREE'd.  was causing
    segfaults.
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml.rb: Moved docs to proper place.
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml/rubytypes.rb: dump symbols as implicits. [ruby-talk:94930]
- lib/gram.y: Fixed root-level inline collections.

- ext/ruby/lib/yaml.rb: Kernel#y changes.  Thanks Joel! [ruby-talk:94890]
- ext/ruby/samples/okayRpc-client.rb: Formatting of output.
no more ~ on dump
adding yaml2xml

- ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: Timestamp round-tripping.
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml/rubytypes.rb: Better Range emission.
- ext/ruby/tests/basic.rb: Tests for the above.
- lib/gram.y: New inline collection flexibilities.
- lib/syck.h: Version 0.43.

- ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: Handling of sexagesimal digits.
- lib/implicit.re: Ditto.
- lib/emitter.c: Fixes from ruby-core.

- lib/ruby/rubytypes.rb: fix for anonymous structs
- tests/basic.rb: test from [ruby-core:01946]
- lib/syck.c: Revert to previous buffering with full max_size.  [ruby-core:01834]
- lib/syck.h: Version 0.42.

- ext/token.re: Removed many YYTOKTMP references.  Were completely throwing
    the parser into buffer overflow.
win32 settings
dos2unix
oops wrong directory
added ypath testing
disclaimre added
adding dump and ypath from PyYaml so only one package is needed
seems useful
made error into a tuple so I can get the line/column
added error handling

update setup.py to use local build dir,
a bit of formatting to fit 80 columns.

- lib/bytecode.c: Fixed problems with empty nested collections.  Started work on complex keys.
- lib/yaml2byte.c: Bug in strings preventing multiple newlines, empty strings.

- lib/yaml2byte.c: YAML-to-bytecode handler.
- lib/yamlbyte.h: Ditto.
- lib/bytecode.re: Tag allocation fix.
- lib/syck.c: Buffer underlow fix.
- ext/ruby/tests/basic.rb: Additional bytecode tests.
- lib/gram.y: Elimination of '+' terminal.

- lib/syck.h: Version 0.41
- lib/bytecode.c: Checkin of generated re2c output.

- lib/bytecode.re: Handling of implicit and taguri tags.
- ext/ruby/tests/basic.rb: Further unit tests for bytecode.
- lib/bytecode.re: Additional bytecode work (alias, anchors, etc.)

- lib/bytecode.re: Fixed nested collections.
- ext/ruby/tests/basic.rb: Starting bytecode unit tests.
- lib/bytecode.re: Further bytecode support.
- lib/bytecode.re: Beginning bytecode parser.
- lib/implicit.re: Using the 'tag' URI rather than 'taguri'.
- README.BYTECODE: initial checkin.

- ext/python/pyext.c: building node class.
- lib/token.re: comment lookahead to ease flexibility.
- ext/python/ext/pyext.c: formatting.

- ext/python/pyext.c: implementing syck.Node class.
- lib/syck.h: decreased buffer size increased performance.
- ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: support for default value.
adding both forms of the API, plus the WHOLE_SCALAR bytecode
syck to yaml bytecodes

- ext/python/pyext.c: introduced yaml_org_handler as seen in yaml.rb.
    started parse handler.
- ext/python/tests/basic.py: no booleans, no strings
- ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: dumb comment -- out!

- lib/token.re: Tokenizer was ignoring root-level spaces in a document
    without a header.

- lib/yaml/rubytypes.rb: Regexp::POSIXLINE deprecated.  Using Regexp::MULTILINE.
    Thanks anonymous sourceforge user.
- lib/implicit.re: spelling error 'xprivate' in syck_type_id_to_taguri().

- ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: refactoring of the transfer method
    dispatch.  added yaml_org_handler for faster handling of
    transfers to base types.

- ext/ruby/lib/yaml/rubytypes.rb: removed handling of builtins from
    Ruby library.

- lib/handler.c: memory leak fix. thanks Sven.

- lib/token.re: quoted and block scalars are now implicit !str

- lib/implicit.re: empty string detected as a null.

- lib/syck.h: no nested declarations for HP-UX compiler.

- lib/handler.c: Memory leaks.  Thanks Sven Verdoolaege.
- lib/syck.c: SYMID now always > 1 from syck_add_sym().
- ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: Tainting bug from Marshal fixed here.
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml/store.rb: filename is first argument.  Thanks Kent Dahl.

- ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: nuked some warnings, added tainting check.
- lib/gram.y: Added prefixes to a few tokens.

- ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: Emitter now flushes at byte count.
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml.rb: Anchors outputing.
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml/baseemitter.rb: Turned off seq-map shortcut.
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml/stream.rb: Work on doc separators in emission.
- lib/emitter.c: Started base64 built-in encoding/decoding.
- lib/token.re: URI escaping.

- ext/ruby/: Fixed a few tests for the Emitter.  Hacked up a solution to the
    options hash.

- lib/emitter.c: Emitter functions.
- ext/ruby/ext/syck/: Added Emitter class.

- ext/syck/gram.y: added grammar for certain empty sequence entries.
- ext/syck/handler.c, ext/syck/syck.c, ext/syck/syck.h: track bad anchors.
- ext/syck/token.re: added pause token, tag possible circular references.
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml.rb: reintroduced YAML::try_implicit.
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml/rubytypes.rb: parsing YMD time as Date instance.
- ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: ditto. DomainType, PrivateType, BadAlias classes.
    merge key now handled.

- ext/ruby/lib/yaml/constants.rb: removed '\z' escape.
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml/emitter.rb: bug in seq_map_shortcut.
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml/encoding.rb: removed iconv Ruby code.
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml/rubytypes.rb: better String round-tripping.  [ruby-core:1134]
- lib/implicit.re: added !merge key
- lib/token.re: prepended newlines in a block.

- ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: a bit much on the ruby GC.
- ext/ruby/lib/okay/rpc.rc: fault responses fixed.
- lib/token.re: recursion in the INLINEX production in Plain scalars.
- lib/yaml.rb: added YAML::transfer.

- ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: using GC nodes caused segfault. [ruby-core:1071]
- lib/token.c: directives choked on a period.
- lib/gram.y: anchors work above a collection. [ruby-core:1071]
- lib/handler.c, lib/syck.c: ensure a fresh strtable between
  parser iterations.
- lib/gram.y: solved anchor problem in map collections.
Release 0.33

- lib/gram.y: flexibility for transfers and anchors on collections.
- lib/token.re: comments eaten on scalar block headers.
- ext/ruby/lib/yaml/basenode.rb: was throwing errors on YPath. thanks, bruce.

- lib/token.re: added hexadecimal escapes.
- ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: bug in mktime.
- ext/ruby/tests/basic.rb: my unit tests for the Ruby module.
* lib/token.re: forced indent and nl keep fixes.
* lib/syck.h: version 0.32

* ext/python/tests/basic.py: two tests were erroneous.

* lib/gram.y: flexibility for anchors, aliases.

* lib/handler.c, lib/syck.h: removed syck_fold_format.

* lib/token.re: all folding handled for plains and blocks in tokenizer.

* lib/yaml.rb (YAML::object_maker): can create object attributes (such as found
  in Exception class)

* lib/yaml/rubytypes.rb: roundtripping of Exception and subclasses.
* lib/token.re: also found problems with quoted scalars at root-level.

* lib/token.re: transfer method bug, \0-ending charsets allowed.

* lib/gram.y: empty document separator allowed.

* ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: now returning Qnil on error.
Fix to show proper line numbers.  Tokenizer was double-counting some lines.

* lib/gram.y: fixes to one-line documents and end of stream.

* lib/syck.c, lib/syck.h: added root_on_error symbol to define a default
  return value upon a parse error.

* ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c, lib/implicit.re: timestamp repair to timezone and milliseconds.

* lib/syck.c: no nobu warning.

* lib/syck.c: memory leak in parser level domains.

* added extraneous files.
* lib/gram.y: transfer methods on sequences inside of sequences.
* lib/gram.y: memory leak when merging maps.

* ext/ruby/ext/syck/rubyext.c: func prototypes for VC++.

* ext/python/tests/basic.py: added seq_in_map test.

* lib/gram.y: at long last! seq_in_map implemented!

* ext/ruby/lib/yaml.rb: now using YAML::Syck glue code.

* ext/ruby/lib/yaml/ypath.rb: ']' quoted in regexp.

* ext/ruby/lib/yaml/: Object#object_id fix from Tanaka Akira.

* lib/token.re: Removed some escape sequences in favor of octal.  Thanks to U. Nakamura for finding.

* lib/syck.h: Typedef for st_data_t.

Portable comments, NULL misuse, VALUE returns in Ruby extension.
Resolution of transfer method on mapping.

Transfer methods in native loading.
Implicit mappings and sequences tagged.
Fixed bad transfer methods.

Type ID -> TAGURI functions.
Ruby extension now includes Loader class, changes incident to Ruby 1.8 checkin.
Versioning for 0.25.
Extension now builds with install.rb and the rest of the YAML.rb dist.
Solved problem with parsers not being reusable.

Integrating Syck and YAML.rb.
Improvements to YAML::Syck::Node class.
Multiline plain values.
Better literal blocks.  Empty literals were whacked.  Had some back SyckLevels throwing off forced indentation of literals in sequences.
Double- and single-quoted strings now have proper whitespace and ASCII escapes.

Better comment handling.
Better indentation.
Better plains.
Better sequences.

Fixed block scalars in nested indentation.
Still working on a fix for transfer method ambiguity on mappings.

Added map-in-seq shortcut.
Started figuring out seq-in-map shortcut.
Added Python tests.
Minor optimizations.

Funniness going on with indentation + comments.  Fixed.
More tests for Python.

Fixed line breaks in inline collections.
Initial support for comments.
Fixed a bunch of memory leaks in Syck and the testing suite.
Stream parsing fix.

More stream parsing.
Better handling of literals.
Safety check on S_MEMMOVE.

Ruby extension now features a reentrant parser and stream loading.
Folks, we are just about ready to do a YAML.rb 0.60.
Folding is quite good now.

Floats in PHP, Python.
Literal parsing, chomping, keeping, explicit indent.  It's all there.

Floats.
IO handling in Ruby.
IO read working.

Adding YAML.rb remains.
Uh.. more work on Syck I guess.
Checkins from YAML.rb.
Updates to the PHP, Python extensions.
URI prefixing.  Separator bug fix.

Taguris now available for all types.
S_FREE macro.
Ruby cNode class, Syck::parse, and directives.
Config dir.  Automake errors suppressed.
Semicolons.
Added some text.

Time implicits, better whitespace parsing.
Gettin better all the time.
Scalar blocks.  Better whitespace handling.

Broke off the implicit expressions into implicit.re and implicit.c.
Provided the ITRANSFER token for the "!" implicit transfer.
Python implicits.

Now parsing integer, null, and boolean implicits.
Ruby extension updated to handle them.
Temp token pointer added to parser struct.
Started implicit scalar parsing.
Better error-reporting: line number, column now available.
RE2C suffix in lib/Makefile.am.
Basic indentation parsing.
Switched to RE2C lexer.
PHP extension.

Better free'ing of nodes.  Each node is free'd after it is symbolized.
(Except anchors which are free'd after the document is done.)
Python extension working!  Rearrangement of st lib.  Addition of level counter.
Python extension.  Symbol table within SyckParser.
Freeing the parser in the ruby-ext.
Doc separators.
Anchors and aliases working!
Inline array tokens.
Parser and tokenizer hooked up.  Ruby extension checkin.
Hooking up the tokenizer.
Continuing work on parser, IO.
Starting on tokenizer.  Parser allocation, structure.

Quick finish of the grammar.  I eliminated handling of the "<=" merge key in
the parser.  The seq-map shortcut is also commented out until I determine how
I'd like this parsed.

Next step is to get some simple YAML examples parsing.

Nodes no longer form a tree.  The symbol table will connect the nodes.
I've introduced st.c and st.h from the Ruby distribution to handle testing
the symbol table and as a compile option for languages without a helpful
symbol table.

In the Ruby 1.8 dist, we'll leverage Ruby's symbol table directly and
leave out compilation of the the st libs.  Libsyck, on the other hand,
will compile with the symbol table built-in.

Separated node allocation into lib/node.c.
Starting to port YAML.rb grammar to Yacc.
Assert macros.
Allocating now in chunks.  Added a few more allocation tests.
Build, test environment improved.
Initial revision
New repository initialized by cvs2svn.

issue.title: Ambigous license
issue.body: COPYING file says that syck is distributed under BSD license, however MIT license text is listed instead (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BSD_licenses, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIT_License). Though license terms are similar if not equal, it'd be nice to clarify which specific license is used. I, as package maintainer, am quite confused which license I should specify in the package metadata.

issue.title: EXC_BAD_ACCESS in yamlDescription for non-empty top-level array
Noted hash and spl dependencies.
issue.body:
https://bugs.php.net/bug.php?id=57775

Added dependencies in package.xml for hash and spl.

issue.title: wrong license title
issue.body:
Hi!

I noticed that in the COPYING file, it is indicated that the files are licensed under the BSD or D&R license. However, the text below the title "BSD License" is that of the Expat (former MIT) license. Given that most of the projects of why the luck stiff were licensed under this MIT/Expat license, should we consider that the license to use is Expat instead of BSD?

Best regards,

  Cdric
