Get 100% spec coverage in database.rb
Add specs for Sequel.quote_identifiers, Sequel.use_parse_tree, and Sequel.use_parse_tree=

Add almost full support for PostgreSQL-JDBC, other major changes

This commit enables almost full support for PostgreSQL-JDBC.  The
only thing that isn't supported is that bytea columns are not
returned as SQL::Blobs, they are returned as a proxy to a java
object.  I'm not sure how best to handle the situation, and as I
don't use blobs I'll wait for a patch from someone who cares enough
to fix it.

In order to fully support PostgreSQL-JDBC, the postgres adapter
needed to be split into parts that were adapter dependent and parts
that were not.  Luckily, most parts were not adapter dependent, so
most code is shared between the native (pg, postgres, postgres-pr)
and JDBC postgres adapters.

There isn't any extra support for other JDBC drivers.  I may attempt
to support the MySQL and SQLite JDBC adapters in the future, but I'm
not sure about that yet.  I welcome patches from the community if
you want other databases fully supported using JDBC.

The Base JDBC adapter had a few changes, most notably that it
now converts exceptions into Sequel::Errors.  I only tested this with
PostgreSQL-JDBC, so YMMV on other JDBC adapters.  Also, I added a
usec method to Java::JavaSQL::Timestamp, allowing it to work with
PostgreSQL timestamp literalization.

There are some other changes that are going in along side this
commit.  The first is that the insert, update, and delete Dataset
methods are getting default implementations.  Most adapters shared
the same code, so it's better to have a default implementation than
the same or very similar code in all adapters.  I tried to be
careful when modifying most adapters, since I don't test any but
PostgreSQL, SQLite, and MySQL.  If I broke something, I apologize,
please post a patch on the bugtracker and/or ping me on IRC.

Another change is the addition of the execute_ddl and execute_dui
Database methods.  execute_dui should be used for DELETE, UPDATE,
and INSERT statements, execute_ddl should be used for any DDL
statements (CREATE TABLE, ALTER TABLE, DROP TABLE, etc.).  Most
users will not care about this as they are unlikely to be used
directly.

The Database methods that execute DDL statements use execute_ddl,
and the default implementations of Dataset insert, update, and
delete use execute_dui.  Also, the schema methods that take blocks
that are passed to the schema generators now also take an optional
additional argument specifying an existing generator instead of a
block.  The Model schema methods use this to reduce code duplication.

Model#create_table! now works the same way as Database#create_table!,
in that it drops the table and rescues errors instead of checking if
the table exists.

Some other adapter changes:

Informix - execute is now an alias of query, do is an alias of the
old execute method, which is now named execute_dui.  This change
was made for consistency, and should not affect you unless you
were calling the method directly.

Postgres - string_to_bool is now a singleton method of the
Sequel::Postgres module instead of the Sequel::Postgres::Adapter
class.  This is unlikely to affect you unless you were using the
method directly.
Remove Sequel::Worker
Add integration test for Dataset#insert returning primary key

Add more integration tests, fix PostgreSQL insert without primary key

This adds a couple of integration tests for simple dataset operations
and for schema parsing, adding tables, and adding/removing columns
to/from tables.  I'm adding these now because there is going to be
some significant refactoring happening relatively soon and I want to
be extra sure that nothing gets broken.

The integration suite already found one bug with the PostgreSQL
adapter, that raised an error trying to insert a record into a table
without a primary key.  This commit fixes that.

This commit also makes the SQLite adapter not override the
alter_table add_column case, since the default does work.
Remove match_expr method from MySQL and PostgreSQL datasets (unused now that ParseTree support has been removed)
Update CHANGELOG to reflect JDBC and uri_to_options changes
Load sequel_core before spec_config in the adapter specs

Automatically load the JDBC driver class (fixes #233), JDBC changes, SQLite refactoring

This commit should automatically load the JDBC driver for MySQL,
PostgreSQL, SQLite, Oracle, and MSSQL.  It passes the connection
string given to Sequel.connect directly to JDBC, so you should put
your username and password (if necessary), directly in the connection
string.  Using the :user and :password options with JDBC is no
longer supported.

This only got testing with JRuby 1.1.2, PostgreSQL 8.3.1, and
PostgreSQL-JDBC 8.2.505.  Hopefully it works with the other database
servers, but I can't promise anything.

This also changes Sequel::JDBC::Database#execute_and_forget to use
executeUpdate instead of executeQuery.  This makes insert, update,
and delete work with PostgreSQL-JDBC, and, from what little I know
about JDBC, is the correct method to use.

This also changes Sequel::Database.uri_to_options.  Before, SQLite
support was special cased here even though it should have been
handled via subclassing (i.e. in Sequel::SQLite::Database). Do that
now, which cleans things up.

Move the URI query options processing from uri_to_options to
connect.  Semantically probably the wrong move, but more practical,
as subclasses are going to want the same behavior, and it saves
coding in subclasses.

Finally, make Database.uri_to_options a private class method.  I
can't think of a reason that a user would need access to it.

Don't assume from this commit that everything works probably using
JDBC.  Currently, with PostgreSQL-JDBC, only the bare minimum is
supported (you are probably much better off with postgres-pr, for
the time being). To get true support, the dataset classes need to
be split from the adapters.  This will come in time, and as usual,
patches will speed things up.
Make Oracle adapter work with a nonstandard Oracle database port

Typecast '' to nil by default for non-string non-blob columns, add typecast_empty_string_to_nil= model class and instance methods

This is mainly to ease web development using Sequel, where '' would
generally be the value returned by a select box for an integer column
when nothing is selected.  It will also help any time you are using
Sequel with values extracted out of a text based file (such as csv),
where the empty string for an integer field is used to express NULL.

I've given this quite a bit of thought about whether to make this
option true by default.  In general, Sequel does not go out of its
way to make web development easier, defaulting to options that are
strict and will generally be changed for web development, such as
strict_param_setting and typecast_on_assignment.  However, both of
those features are generally only changed if you want to display
nice error messages to the user, because they only change the
behavior when the submitted data is malformed.  In this case, Sequel
would be raising an error during normal use.  It's a tough call to
make, but ultimately I think that typecasting to nil is the better
default.

Like many of the other options, this is modifiable at the global,
class, and instance levels:

  Sequel::Model.typecast_empty_string_to_nil = false
  Artist.typecast_empty_string_to_nil = false
  artist = Artist.new
  artist.typecast_empty_string_to_nil = false
Use a simpler select in Dataset#empty?, fixes use with MySQL

Add integration test suite, testing sequel against a real database, with nothing mocked

After a long wait, I've finally put together an integration test
suite for sequel.  Currently, it only covers the examples shown in
the advanced_associations.rdoc file, but hopefully now that it is
here, more people will contribute real specs.

The integration specs have two ways of running, one where the
database is specified, and one where it is not.  If the database is
not specified, it uses a sqlite memory database, and addition to
checking for the correct functionality, it also checks that the
correct SQL is being issued to the server.  If the database is
specified, it uses that database and ignores the SQL (since it can
be different depending on the database).  This gives the best of
both worlds, the ability to check that sequel works with real
databases, and the ability to see what SQL sequel is actual issuing
to the server when nothing is mocked.  Incidently, a prototype of
this test suite is what helped me discover the Database#columns bug.

You can run the integration test suite with "rake integration", and
configure it via the INTEGRATION_URL constant in spec_config.rb, or
via the SEQUEL_INTEGRATION_URL environment variable.

While here, change the MYSQL_DB and POSTGRES_DB examples in
spec_config.rb to MYSQL_URL and POSTGRES_URL, as it is preferable to
use the URL instead of DB constant.

Make validates_length_of default tag depend on presence of options passed to it

This fixes the issue where prior calls to validates_length_of for the
same attribute get ignored.  That is true of the other validations as
well, but there is no reason to use any of them twice.
validates_length_of could easily get used twice, once for :maximum and
once for :minimum with different error messages specified for each,
for example.

Combine sequel and sequel_core into one gem

For merging the READMEs, I put the model README at the bottom of the
core README and used that.

For merging the CHANGELOGs, I merged them manually back to 1.4.0, and
copied the rest of the model CHANGELOG to the bottom of the file.

Most of the Rakefile code was duplicative, but I think I got
all tasks except spec_adapters.  I figure few people have all 5
adapters necessary to run the adapter specs.  I only have 3 of them,
so I never used spec_adapters.

The specs are still split up so they can be run independently.
Additionally, the adapter specs are split off from the core specs,
which helps if you want to put Sequel.connect lines in
spec_config.rb. The only other spec changes were for path changes.

There weren't conflicts merging anything else, IIRC.

I hope there is no fallout from this.  I haven't noticed any yet,
running the specs and the test suites for all of my apps that use
Sequel.
Bump version to 2.2.0
Fix some minor documentation issues
Add Model.unfiltered class method that calls dataset method

Major refactoring of association internals

Implement the association methods with standard instance methods that
accept the AssociationReflection in addition to any arguments.

Move many methods from the Associations module (where they ended up
being Model private class methods) to the AssociationReflection class.

Add more methods governing behavior to AssociationReflection, which
should make it much easier to add new association types to Sequel.

Add AssociationReflection::ASSOCIATION_TYPES containing the allowed
association types, people wishing to implement new association
types should add to this array.

Add a single Model class method for eager loading, instead of creating
one method per association.

Add :extend association option, for extending a dataset with module(s)

Update the advanced_associations.rdoc file to show a cool usage of
this.
Fix :quote_identifiers and :single_threaded Database options

Expand the advanced_associations.rdoc file

All examples have now been tested, and an integration test suite will
be committed soon starting with some of these examples.

Add :after_load association callback

This lets you run code after the associated items have been loaded
from the database.

Also, this lets you specify a nil :key option for a many_to_one
association.  If specified the query will load all records for
the association, and just give you the first one.  This allows
many_to_one to work correctly with datasets that use eager_graph,
as well as with associations where there is no foreign key in the
current table, or when both are true (which is possible for a
has_one :through style association).

Only select table.* by default for many_to_many associations

For other association types, it is not needed, and using it caused
problems if you wanted to use a :dataset option that included
an eager_graph call.  Now select is only called on the dataset
if it is specifically set or many_to_many is used.  If you want
many_to_many to select all columns, you can use :select=>nil.

While here, add documentation for the callback options.

Cloned datasets no longer ignore the existing columns unless it is necessary

This bug took me a while to track down.  It shows how much Sequel
really needs an integration test suite (I actually found it while
working on a prototype for the test suite).  Because Dataset#columns
needs access to the database to get results, it is mocked in almost
all specs.

This bug didn't cause any problems, since it would always get the
same columns back from the database, but it did cause a lot of
pointless queries.
Update sequel_core/CHANGELOG for samsouder's tinyint patch

Filter blocks now yield a SQL::VirtualRow argument, which is useful if another library defines operator methods on Symbol

VirtualRow instances return Identifiers, QualifiedIdentifiers, or
Functions for any method called on them, depending on how the method
is called:

* Function - returned if any arguments are supplied, using the method
  name as the function name, and the arguments as the function
  arguments.
* QualifiedIdentifier - returned if the method name contains __, with
  the table being the part before __, and the column being the part
  after.
* Identifier - returned otherwise, using the method name.

Examples:

  ds = DB[:t]
  ds.filter{|r| r.name < 2} # SELECT * FROM t WHERE (name < 2)
  ds.filter{|r| r.table__column + 1 < 2} # SELECT * FROM t WHERE ((table.column + 1) < 2)
  ds.filter{|r| r.is_active(1, 'arg2')} # SELECT * FROM t WHERE is_active(1, 'arg2')
Rename blockless_filters_spec.rb to expression_filters_spec.rb
Remove use_parse_tree = false reference in expression filter spec

Add Symbol#identifier method, to make x__a be treated as "x__a" instead of "x"."a"

You can also create identifiers without using Symbols, by using the
Sequel::SQL::Identifier.new("column").  This is much more verbose
but is useful if you want an identifier without using a symbol.

This is mainly being added to support the next commit.
Clean up the expression filter spec

Remove ParseTree support, the expression syntax is now the only available syntax inside blocks

Sequel.use_parse_tree always returns false, and
Sequel.use_parse_tree= raises an Error if the argument given is true.

Other than the the obvious change to the syntax inside blocks, the
only significant change is that update no longer takes a block. As
update only makes sense for equality, a block would not add any value
over using a hash argument.  Before, it was necessary to take a block
to do things like x = x + 1, but that has been easily done with
{:x=>:x + 1} since Sequel 2.0.0.

No longer include the deprecation feature, but still leave it in the
repository for future use.
Fix spelling and cover corner case in :descendants eager loading example in advanced_associations.rdoc

Unbreak Sequel when used with ruby-postgres or postgres-pr

Note that depending on the settings of your postgresql server, the
escaping of strings and byteas may be incorrect unless you use
ruby-pg, especially if you are using settings like backslash_quote
= off or standard_conforming_strings = on.

Also, support bytea type when using postgres-pr.
Update sequel_core/CHANGELOG for abhay's SQLite drop_column support
add support for a 'fake' drop column in sqlite3

Make validation methods support a :tag option, to work correctly with source reloading

If a validation has a :tag option, it overwrites a previous
validation block with the same tag and attribute (if any), similar to
how tags work with hooks.

All validates_*_of methods set the tag to * by default (e.g.
validates_uniqueness_of uses a :tag of :uniqueness by default). This
breaks backwards compatibility slightly, if you have two of the same
type of validations on the same attribute.  If that is the case, add
a different tag to one or both.

While here, refactor the :if option handling to be less verbose.
Also, document all of the supported options to the validates_*_of
methods, as well as some other documentation improvements.
Add doc/advanced_associations.rdoc file, showing off how powerful and flexible Sequel::Model associations are

Add :before_add, :after_add, :before_remove, :after_remove association callback options

These mirror the association callback capabilities of ActiveRecord.
Each of these options can be a Symbol specifying an instance method
that takes one argument (the associated object), or a Proc that takes
two arguments (the current object and the associated object).

If any of the before callbacks return false, the adding/removing
does not happen and it either raises an error (the default), or
returns nil (if raise_on_save_failure is false).

All callbacks are also run on many_to_one associations.  If there
was already an existing object for the association, it calls the
remove callbacks on the existing object and the add callbacks on the
new object.  The remove callback calls are placed around the add
callback calls.

This also separates the many_to_one setter (association=) method into
two parts, the public association= method, and the private
_association= method that actually sets the foreign key.  This is
necessary to support polymorphic associations, where another column
would also need to be changed, and probably in other cases as well.

This also changes the many_to_one setter logic somewhat, as it
doesn't just look in the associations cache for an existing object,
it just calls the association method, which means using the setter
can cause database access.  This was necessary to make sure the
remove callback methods worked correctly for many_to_one
associations.

The many_to_one setter now exits early if the object passed to it
is the same as the existing object.

Cleanup samsouder's convert_tinyint_to_bool patch

Always use teardown for cleanup actions, so failures in tests don't
cause spurious errors in later tests.

Slightly cleaner handling in schema_column_type.
Merge branch 'mysamsouder' into samsoudermerge
Fix typo in Model.associate RDoc

- added accessor (Sequel.convert_tinyint_to_bool, defaulting to true) to allow modification of converting tinyints to booleans
- modified Schema::SQL#schema_column_type to obey the Sequel.convert_tinyint_to_bool switch
- modified Mysql::Result#convert_type to use Sequel.convert_tinyint_to_bool when fetching results
- added MYSQL_USER to spec configuration to allow for variation in local MySQL setup when doing tests
- modified mysql spec tests to use the MYSQL_USER for connections
- added onto mysql spec tests to test the Sequel.convert_tinyint_to_bool accessor
Fix postgres spec failure when standard_conforming_strings = on

Model.validates_presence_of now considers false as present instead of absent

This makes it usable for NOT NULL boolean fields.

Add Model.raise_on_save_failure, raising errors on save failure instead of return false (now nil), default to true

This breaks backwards compatibility, but I believe it is the correct
default for most non-web-apps.  The problem with just returning a
value is that the return value is often not checked, and I think that
invalid data should be treated as an exceptional condition by
default.

Like the strict_param_setting and typecast_on_assignment setting,
you can turn this off/on at the global, class, and instance level:

  Sequel::Model.raise_on_save_failure = false # Global
  Artist.raise_on_save_failure = true # Class
  artist = Artist.new
  artist.raise_on_save_failure = false # Instance

Backwards compatibility is even slightly broken if you turn it off,
as save and it's variants will now return nil instead of false. The
exception is save_changes, which will now have the same behavior as
before, returning nil if no columns changed, and false if the save
fails.

Do not apply the :limit association option when eager loading

Using :limit when eager loading will lead to wrong results in most
cases, so ignore that option when eager loading.  Note that eager
loading on a limited dataset still works correctly, it is just the
:limit association option that is ignored.

Applying the :limit association option was recently added, but it
is obviously wrong. Not sure what I was thinking when I added it.

Allow the use of URL parameters in connection strings

Among other things, this allows you to specify a socket path as a
host name in a postgresql connection string:

  postgres://user:password@ignored/db_name?host=/tmp

Add :eager_loader association option, to specify code to be run when eager loading

:eager_loader is powerful option that allows you to completely
specify how associations are to be eagerly loaded.  It is flexible
enough that it can be used to eagerly load association types that
Sequel doesn't even natively support, such as polymorphic
associations.  The eager loading code has been greatly simplified as
it now just uses the :eager_loader option, which has defaults that
are the same as the previous eager loading behavior.

:eager_loader should be a proc that takes 3 arguments, a key_hash,
an array of records, and a hash of dependent associations.  Since you
are given all of the records, you can do things like filter on
associations that are specified by multiple keys, or do multiple
queries depending on the content of the records (which would be
necessary for polymorphic associations).  Inside the :eager_loader
proc, you should get the related objects and populate the
associations for all objects in the array of records.  The hash
of dependent associations is available for you to cascade the eager
loading down multiple levels, but it is up to you to use it.  The
key_hash is a performance enhancement that is used by the default
code and is also available to you.  It is a hash with keys being
foreign/primary key symbols in the current table, and the values
being hashes where the key is foreign/primary key values and values
being arrays of current model objects having the foreign/primary key
value associated with the key.  This is hard to visualize, so I'll
give an example:

  album1 = Album.load(:id=>1, :artist_id=>2)
  album2 = Album.load(:id=>3, :artist_id=>2)
  Album.many_to_one :artist
  Album.one_to_many :tracks
  Album.eager(:band, :tracks).all
  # The key_hash provided to the :eager_loader proc would be:
  {:id=>{1=>[album1], 3=>[album2]}, :artist_id=>{2=>[album1, album2]}}

Make :many_to_one associations support :dataset, :order, :limit association options, as well as block arguments

This makes the many_to_one association code use the same
infrastructure as the other association code for getting records.
This also makes it create a _dataset method for many_to_one
associations, just as it does for other associations.  Because the
same infrastructure is used, it automatically supports the :order,
:limit (to specify offset), and :dataset options, as well as a block
argument.

This can be used to set up ActiveRecord has_one-style associations,
by using a :dataset option, instead of using a one_to_many
association with the :one_to_one option:

  Band.many_to_one :band_info, :key=>:id, \
    :dataset=>proc{BandInfo.filter(:band_id => id)}

This commit also refactors some private association methods to remove
the redundant name argument, since it is included in the
AssociationReflection.

Refactor add_/remove_/remove_all_ association method creation

This adds the add_reciprocal_object and remove_reciprocal_object
instance methods to Sequel::Model, which makes it possible to merge
the add_/remove_/remove_all_ methods created by many_to_many and
one_to_many associations.  This simplifies the code and should be
more readable.

Also, remove some symbol proliferation in the many_to_many case.

Add :dataset association option, which overrides the default base dataset to use

The :dataset option should be a proc, which is instance_evaled to get
the base dataset to use.  It is currently only used for :one_to_many
and :many_to_many associations, but will be extended to :many_to_one
associations soon.

Some examples of use:

  Artist.one_to_many :albums_not_by, :class=>:Album, \
    :dataset=>proc{Album.filter(:artist_id=>pk).invert}

  Album.many_to_many :genres, \
    :dataset=>proc{Genre.join_table(:natural, :albums_genres) \
      .filter(:albums_genres__nodeid=>pk)}
Qualify foreign keys when loading associations so they play nicely with the :eager_graph option

Add the :eager_graph association option, works just like :eager except it uses #eager_graph

This doesn't work perfectly yet, as the association filters don't use
qualified columns.  That will be fixed in a later commit.

Ignore any previous selected columns when using Dataset#graph for the first time

This may break backwards compatibility a little bit, but it was
always recommended to use set_graph_aliases instead of select
when using eager_graphing.  I'm pretty sure the previously
selected columns where ignored, but it caused the primary table
not to show up in the result graph.

While here, refactor Dataset#set_graph_aliases to reduce symbol
proliferation.
Make eager loading via #eager respect the :limit association option

Add :graph_join_table_join_type association option

This can be used to specify the type of SQL join to use for the join
table when eagerly loading the association via #eager_graph.  It
defaults to the :graph_join_type option, or :left_outer if that
is not used.

Add :graph_only_conditions and :graph_join_table_only_conditions association options

These allow you to override the default conditions specified via the
foreign/primary keys.  They can be used to specify NATURAL joins or
USING joins.  When using these options, you can specify any condition
that Dataset#join_table will accept.  If you use a hash or an array
of all two pairs, it will qualify unqualified columns the same way
it usual does in Dataset#join_table.  Examples:

  # Artist primary key is artist_id, same as foreign key in albums
  # table.  This will do a JOIN USING.
  Artist.one_to_many :albums, :graph_only_conditions=>[:artist_id]
  # Same, but assumes that all columns in both tables are unique,
  # except for the key columns.  This will do a NATURAL JOIN.
  Artist.one_to_many :albums, :graph_only_conditions=>nil, \
    :graph_join_type=>:natural
Reduce symbol proliferation in #eager_graph

Add support for :graph_block and :graph_join_table_block association options

These allow you to specify arbitrary conditions on joins when eager loading
via eager_graph.  For example:

  Artist.one_to_many(:gold_albums, :class=>Album, \
    :graph_block=>proc{|ja,lja,js| :copies_sold.qualify(ja) > 500000}) \
    do |ds|
    ds.filter(:copies_sold > 500000)
  end
Refactor Dataset#graph to reduce symbol proliferation

Dataset#graph now accepts a block which is passed to join_table

This also makes the join_conditions argument for #graph optional,
just as it is optional for #join_table.

Make Dataset#columns ignore any filtering, ordering, and distinct clauses

I don't think this should have any fallout.  The only possible issue
I can think of is using an SQL function with side effects inside one
of those clauses and expecting it to be called inside #columns.

Set the model's dataset's columns in addition to the model columns when loading the schema

This should save a query (potentially many queries) to get the
columns for model datasets.

Use the safer connection-specific string escaping methods for PostgreSQL

Remove the Sequel::Postgres::Adapter.quote method, as well as the
TRUE, FALSE, and NULL constants in Sequel::Postgres::Adapter.  Handle
all of the escaping inside Sequel::Postgres::Dataset#literal.  There
shouldn't be any breakage from this, unless you were using the
Adapter.quote method directly.

It probably hurts performance slightly to use the connection-specific
string escape methods, since we have to acquire a connection for
every attempt to literalize a string, but safety is more important.

The one corner case I can think of where this approach may pose an
issue is if you cannot acquire a connection right away.  It will wait
for a connection to become available, or even throw a
PoolTimeoutError if it can't acquire a connection.  We might be able
to work around that by using any already allocated connection, but
I'm not sure if that is safe.
Database#transaction now yields a connection when using the Postgres adapter, just like it does for other adapters
Update sequel_core/CHANGELOG for recent contributions
Merge branch 'mydivoxx'
added support for add index to the sqlite adapter
super stupid fix for Sequel's desire for Symbols killing ActiveRecord's expectations of Strings.

Use COUNT_FROM_SELF_OPTS to implement count w/ limit

Change implementation to use COUNT_FROM_SELF_OPTS and from_self method
to implement count of dataset w/ limit defined
Fixing bug that COUNT wouldn't consider LIMIT of the dataset

Treat Hash as expression instead of column alias when used in DISTINCT, ORDER BY, and GROUP BY clauses

Add Dataset#expression_list, used instead of #column_list for the
DISTINCT, ORDER BY, and GROUP BY clauses.  Using aliases for columns
in these clauses is invalid, and none of these columns can take the
* wildcard, so using column_list doesn't make sense.  Because
column_list used literal for all values except a hash, this doesn't
change much code, and shouldn't break any existing code.  This is
the main change this commit makes:

  Before:
    DB[:items].order(:price=>nil) # ORDER BY price AS ""
  After:
    DB[:items].order(:price=>nil) # ORDER BY (price IS NULL)

The new SQL was possible before, and it still works:

  DB[:items].order({:price=>nil}.sql_expr) # ORDER BY (price IS NULL)
Unbreak MySQL adapter and update sequel_core/CHANGELOG for dlee's bytea fix
Type detection for blobs
Finalize support for postgres blobs
Add support for blobs
Make caching work correctly in subclasses
Add the Model.to_hash dataset method
For PostgreSQL, don't raise an error when assigning a value to a SERIAL PRIMARY KEY field when inserting records
Bump version to 2.1.0
Work correctly if ParseTree isn't available (thanks Tamas)
Remove the RubyForge page link from the READMEs
Minor documentation improvements
Use meta_eval instead of metaclass.instance_eval in core_ext.rb
Don't create unneeded writers for some Sequel::Model class instance variables

Support bitwise operators for NumericExpressions: &, |, ^, ~, <<, >>

NumericExpressions can now use the bitwise operators.  These should
be supported at least on PostgreSQL, SQLite, and MySQL.  Examples:

  :x.sql_number & 1 > 100 # ((x & 1) > 100)
  :x.sql_number | 1 > 100 # ((x | 1) > 100)
  :x.sql_number ^ 1 > 100 # ((x ^ 1) > 100)
  ~:x.sql_number > 100 # (~x > 100)
  :x.sql_number << 1 > 100 # ((x << 1) > 100)
  :x.sql_number >> 1 > 100 # ((x >> 1) > 100)
  (:x + 1) & 1 > 100 # (((x + 1) & 1) > 100)
  (:x + 1) | 1 > 100 # (((x + 1) | 1) > 100)
  (:x + 1) ^ 1 > 100 # (((x + 1) ^ 1) > 100)
  ~(:x + 1) > 100 # (~(x + 1) > 100)
  (:x + 1) << 1 > 100 # (((x + 1) << 1) > 100)
  (:x + 1) >> 1 > 100 # (((x + 1) >> 1) > 100)

Because the &, |, and ~ operators are already overloaded for Symbol,
LiteralString, and SpecificExpression, you can get confusing results
if you assume to get numeric behavior from those operators.  For
example:

  :x & y # (x AND y)
  :x | y # (x OR y)
  ~:x # NOT x
  :x ^ :y # !! NoMethodError
  :x << :y # !! NoMethodError
  :x >> :y # !! NoMethodError

You need to make sure that the values are NumericExpressions before
using the bitwise operators:

  :x.sql_number & y # (x & y)
  :x.sql_number | y # (x | y)
  ~:x.sql_number # ~x
  :x.sql_number ^ :y # (x ^ y)
  :x.sql_number << :y # (x << y)
  :x.sql_number >> :y # (x >> y)

Note that using a regular mathematical operator transforms the result
into a NumericExpression, so the following examples work:

  (:x + 1) & y # ((x + 1) & y)
  (:x + 1) | y # ((x + 1) | y)
  ~(:x + 1) # ~(x + 1)
  (:x + 1) ^ y # ((x + 1) ^ y)
  (:x + 1) << y # ((x + 1) << y)
  (:x + 1) >> y # ((x + 1) >> y)

Break association add_/remove_/remove_all_ methods into two parts, for easier overriding

This adds new private _add_/_remove_/_remove_all_ methods for each
association, that do the actual database work, without mucking with
any of the association cache/reciprocal handling.  This makes it very
easy to override the methods to do what you want, without having to
worry about the caching/reciprocal handling features.

Add Model.strict_param_setting, on by default, which raises errors if a missing/restricted method is called via new/set/update/etc.

This is settable on a global, per class, and per object basis, just
like typecast_on_assignment:

  Sequel::Model.strict_param_setting = false # Global
  Artist.strict_param_setting = true # Per Class
  artist = Artist.new
  artist.strict_param_setting = true # Per Object

Unless it is turned off (since it is on by default), it will raise
an error if an missing or restricted method is used.  For example:

  Artist.set_restricted_columns :z
  Artist.new(:z=>1) # Error
  Artist.create(:z=>1) # Error
  artist = Artist.new
  artist.set(:z=>1) # Error
  artist.update(:z=>1) # Error
  artist.set_all(:typecast_on_assignment=>true) # Error
  artist.update_all(:id=>1) # Error
  artist.set_only({:x=>1}, :y) # Error
  artist.set_except({:x=>1}, :x) # Error
  artist.update_only({:x=>1}, :y) # Error
  artist.update_except({:x=>1}, :x) # Error

Raise errors when using association methods on objects without valid primary keys, and better removing of objects from cached values

This makes the association methods raise an error if they are called
on objects without valid primary keys.  For example:

  Album.many_to_one :artist
  Artist.one_to_many :albums
  artist = Arist.new
  album = Album[1]

  # many_to_one getter always works
  album.artist # no error
  # many_to_one setter fails if passed object doesn't have a valid
  # primary key (though it works with nil to unset it)
  album.artist = artist # error

  # All one_to_many methods raise an error if the current object
  # doesn't have a valid primary key
  artist.albums # error
  artist.albums_dataset # error
  artist.add_album(album) # error
  artist.remove_album(album) # error
  artist.remove_all_albums # error

  artist.save # sets primary key

  album.artist = artist # no error

  artist.albums # no error
  artist.albums_dataset # no error
  artist.add_album(album) # no error
  artist.remove_album(album) # no error
  artist.remove_all_albums # no error

  Genre.many_to_many :albums
  album = Album[1]
  genre = Genre.new

  # All many_to_many methods raise an error if the current object
  # does not have a valid primary key
  genre.albums # error
  genre.albums_dataset # error
  genre.add_album(album) # error
  genre.remove_album(album) # error
  genre.remove_all_albums # error

  genre.save # sets primary key

  genre.albums # no error
  genre.albums_dataset # no error
  genre.add_album(album) # no error
  genre.remove_album(album) # no error
  genre.remove_all_albums # no error

  album = Album.new

  # Unlike one_to_many associations, many_to_many associations
  # require the passed object to add_/remove_ to have a valid
  # primary key as well as the current object having a valid
  # primary key.
  genre.add_album(album) # error
  genre.remove_album(album) # error

  album.save

  genre.add_album(album) # no error
  genre.remove_album(album) # no error

Also in this is a change in how objects are removed from cached
association arrays.  Before, this was done using a simple delete,
which doesn't work correctly in all (most?) cases.  This was changed
to deleting all objects from the array with the same primary key as
the object given, which should be more reliable, especially now that
objects without valid primary keys should no longer be added to the
arrays, due to the checks described above.

Add migrate options (-m, -M) to the sequel command line tool, and exit properly

The -m option specifies the directory of migration files.

The -M option specifies the version to migrate to.  There is no
option to specify the version to migrate from, you'll have to
use the API for that.

This also changes the exit status to 1 instead of the default 0 in
case of an error.

Allow Dataset #filter, #or, #exclude and other methods that call them to use both the block and regular arguments

Before, the regular arguments would be silently ignored and only the
block arguments would be used.  Now, if both regular and block
arguments are given, both will be used (ANDed together).

Another change is that the following no longer raises an error:

  dataset.filter(true)
  dataset.filter(false)

Previously, this raised an error, the reason given was that it
appeared to be an error.  However, it's perfectly valid to use
a plain boolean condition in a filter call, especially false
as a way of making sure no records get returned (true is really
a no-op).

Deprecate ParseTree filters, allow expression (blockless) filters inside blocks, default to ParseTree filters

ParseTree filters are now officially deprecated and are scheduled for
removal in Sequel 2.2.  They are still the default even though they
are deprecated in order to not immediately break legacy code.

To use the expression (blockless) filters inside blocks, either
set the SEQUEL_NO_PARSE_TREE constant before requiring sequel,
or use Sequel.use_parse_tree = false after requiring it.

Rename Model.sti_key to Model.set_sti_key, and have it set up filters in subclasses

Model.set_sti_key now adds filters to subclasses.  This doesn't work
perfectly for class hierarchies with a depth greater than 2, though.
If you have subclasses of subclasses of the parent STI class, you'll
need to set up the dataset filter in the middle classes manually.

The filter that set_sti_key adds is a simple matching of the sti_key
to the class name.  The class that calls set_sti_key doesn't have
the filter applied to it, so it should get all subclasses.
Revert to using a hash for ConnectionPool#allocated, instead of an associated array
Move requiring of spec_config.rb to the bottom of spec_helper.rb, makes the adapter specs pass when connecting to the database in spec_config.rb

Remove :pool_reuse_connections ConnectionPool/Database option, MySQL users need to be careful with nested queries

The :pool_reuse_connections option is being removed because it could
cause problems with transactions not getting the same database
connection.  The only reason it was added was to prevent MySQL users
from getting an error for this type of query:

  DB[:table1].each{|x| DB[:table2].each{|y| ... }}

MySQL leaves a database cursor open inside each, and it will raise a
"Commands out of sync" error for the above code.  The previous
workaround still works:

  DB[:table1].all{|x| DB[:table2].each{|y| ... }}

The fix is to use all instead of each for the surround query, so the
database query finishes executing before the first call to the block.

Add class methods to restrict which columns are modified in new/set/update, as well as #(set|update)_(all|only|except) to go around them

Model.set_allowed_columns makes it so that only the listed columns are
modified (similar to ActiveRecord's attr_accessible).

Model.set_restricted_columns makes it so that the listed columns are
not modified (similar to ActiveRecord's attr_protected).

Model.unrestrict_primary_key allows you to modify the primary
key in new/set/update.

Model.restrict_primary_key makes the primary key field a
restricted column, and is the default (similar to ActiveRecord).
Being the default, it is only useful in subclasses that have used
unrestrict_primary_key.

Model.restrict_primary_key? returns true/false depending on whether
the primary key is restricted.

Model#(set|update)_(all|only|except ignore the value of
allowed_columns and restricted_columns.  (set|update)_all update
all columns.  (set|update)_only take additional argument(s) specifying
which columns to allow.  (set|update)_except take additional
argument(s) specifying which columns to restrict.  In all cases,
the restrict_primary_key setting remains in effect.

Other setter methods previously callable via new/set/update are no
longer allowed (RESTRICTED_SETTER_METHODS).
Calls to Model.def_dataset_method with a block are cached and reapplied to the new dataset if set_dataset is called, even in a subclass

Store cached associated objects in @associations hash instead of one instance variable per association

This will make it so that you can use associations such as :values,
as well as other names of instance variables.  It also simplifies the
code somewhat, and exposes the cached associations hash via
attr_reader, so you can use it to easily check whether the associated
object(s) has been cached or not.

One small change for this is that the :reciprocal association object
now must provide the symbol name of the association instead of the
name of the instance variable (which was just the name prepended with
@).
Make all associations support a :graph_select option, specifying a column or array of columns to select when using eager_graph
Fix confusing code in after_create example in sequel/README

Allow Dataset#graph :select option to take an array of columns to select

It still allows false to be used not to select columns from the table
and to not include the table in the result set.
Fix typo in dataset_filtering.rdoc
Bring back Model#set and Model#update, now the same as Model#set_with_params and Model#update_with_params

Augment Dataset#to_hash, allowing you to leave off the value argument, or both arguments for model datasets

For all datasets, calling to_hash with only one argument will
result in a hash with keys being the value of the column of argument
given (the key_column), and values will be the entire hash of values.

For model datasets, calling to_hash without any arguments will result
in the primary key being used for the key_column.

These are mainly useful to create lookup tables.  For example, you
could easily implement an identity map for models, or a lookup table
based on the name column.

Add Sequel::Model::DatasetMethods, holding methods other than eager
loading methods that are added to model datasets on the call to
Model.set_dataset.

Move destroy method added to dataset into DatasetMethods.

Remove the now useless include Validation call in sequel_model.rb.
It's only by chance that this didn't break things.

Add Model.sti_key, for easily setting up single table inheritance

Model.sti_key is a simple helper method.  It doesn't add any new
functionality, it just calls some existing methods to make it easy
to set up STI quickly and correctly.  It is only useful if you have
a single string column in your table that contains the name of the
class you would like to use.  Model.sti_key should only be called in
the parent class, not in the subclasses.

The two things it does are:

1) Call dataset.set_model with a hash that results in a valid ruby
class for any key.  If there are problems using the string (like an
empty string or NULL), it uses the class that called sti_key.

2) Add a before_create hook that sets the name of the sti_key column
to the class name, so that when it is loaded from the database, you
get the same class back.

Example:

  class Artist < Sequel::Model
    sti_key :kind
  end
Make all associations support a :read_only option, which doesn't add methods that modify the database
Make *_to_many associations support a :limit option, for specifying a limit to the resulting records (and possibly an offset)

Make association block argument and :eager option affect the _dataset method

This change doesn't break any specs, but it could break behavior if
people relied on _dataset returning just the simple association
dataset.  Previously, only the :order option affected the _dataset
method.  This change was made for consistency purposes, and because
it just seemed like the correct behavior.

Also, this makes the undocumented _helper method private.  The helper
method is used to implement the block argument, since ruby 1.8
doesn't have instance_exec.

Allow join_table to accept a block that provides conditions, and support more types of joins (NATURAL, CROSS, USING)

Some changes:

- You are no longer limited to :inner, :left_outer, :right_outer,
and :full_outer join types.  join_table now accepts any join you
throw at it, so it can generate invalid SQL if you give it bad
input.  This allows you to do the following:

  join_table(:left, :b, ...)
  # LEFT JOIN b ...
  join_table(:my_database_special, :b, ...)
  # MY DATABASE SPECIAL JOIN b ...

- join_table can take an array of symbols as the conditions,
and will create a USING clause from it:

  join_table(:inner, :b, [:id1, :id2])
  # INNER JOIN b USING (id1, id2)

- join_table can accept a nil expr, necessary for NATURAL and CROSS
JOINs.  nil is the default value, so you can just leave it off:

  join_table(:cross, :b)
  # CROSS JOIN b
  join_table(:natural, :b, nil)
  # NATURAL JOIN b

- join_table can take a block that is passed the joined table
alias/name, last joined table (or first source) alias/name, and an
array of previous joins:

  DB[:items___i].join(:blah, nil, :b) \
   do |join_alias, last_join_alias, joins|
    join_alias # :b
    last_join_alias # :i
    joins # [], because no previous joins
  end

- join_table(nil, :t) does "JOIN t" instead of "INNER JOIN t"

- Tables are aliased with AS (before the AS was left out)

  join_table(:cross, :blah, nil, :b)
  # CROSS JOIN blah AS b

- first_source returns the correct alias for a table aliased like
:table___alias.

- Update the MySQL adapter, Oracle adapter, and ODBC_MSSQL adapter
for changes.  The MySQL adapter changes may not be completely
correct, so I encourage testing with real apps.

Make Dataset#count do a subselect when DISTINCT is used

Introduced protected method options_overlap to see if any current
options overlap with the given options, use this in count and
clone.  This is more reliable than the previous method in clone,
which considered an option present if the key existed, even if
the value was nil.
Update CHANGELOG for juco's HAVING patch
Fix spec failures in MySQL and PostgreSQL adapters introduced with recent change

Refactor default SQL generator to generate HAVING clause before
ORDER BY clause in accordance with the SQL-92 spec.

Remove now unecessary code from mysql.rb adapter.

Refactor SQL::Expression subclasses so that methods that don't make sense aren't defined

This refactor fixes some issues, like being able to do:

  :item.desc.as(:blah)

which makes no sense in SQL.

It adds a few new features.  One is a qualify method for symbols
that can add a table/schema qualifier for a column/table name:

  :price.qualify(:items) # items.price

Another are cast_numeric and cast_string, which will cast with
default types (integer and text) and convert the resulting value
to a NumericExpression or StringExpression, so operators that
don't make sense aren't defined (like &).  Example:

  :date.extract(:hour).cast_string + ':00'
  # CAST(extract(hour FROM date) AS text) || ':00'

Also, cast is now the preferred name for the method, instead of
cast_as (which is now an alias to cast).

The ColumnMethods module and ColumnExpr class are going away,
because they combine wildly different semantics with similar
syntax. They are being replaced with separate modules (AliasMethods,
OrderMethods, CastMethods) and classes (OrderedExpression,
AliasedExpression).

There should be very minimal fallout from this:

1) Inverting the order of a dataset will get you ASC if you had DESC,
instead of leaving ASC off.

2) Plain Strings no longer have asc and desc methods, since ordering
by a plain string is a noop.  LiteralStrings still have asc and desc
methods.

3) You can no longer abuse the SQL::Function DSL (Symbol#[]) to
use a table alias with specified columns.  I have no idea if anyone
used this, but it no longer works.  I doubt anyone needs it, so there
isn't a good replacement, other than LiteralString.

The new hierarchy looks like this:

Expression
    ComplexExpression
        BooleanExpression
        NumericExpression
        StringExpression
    GenericExpression
        CaseExpression
        Function
            IrregularFunction
        QualifiedIdentifier
        Subscript
    SpecificExpression
        AliasedExpression
        ColumnAll
        OrderedExpression
Remove Module#metaprivate, since it duplicates the standard Module#private_class_method

Add support for SQL CASE statement via Array#case and Hash#case

Some examples:

  {:a=>:b}.case(:c)
  # CASE WHEN a THEN b ELSE c END
  {(:price * 10 > :max)=>:price - 10}.case(:price)
  # CASE WHEN price * 10 > max THEN price - 10 ELSE price END
  :sum[{{:type=>1}=>1}.case(0)]
  # sum(CASE WHEN type = 1 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END)

If you are specifying multiple conditions, use an array to get
consistent ordering:

  [[:a, :b], [:c, :d]].case(:e)
    # CASE WHEN a THEN b WHEN c THEN d ELSE e END

Using a hash with multiple conditions does work, but since the
order is arbitrary, your conditions should be orthogonal if you
desire deterministic behavior.

Support the SQL EXTRACT function: :date.extract(:year)

Stop abusing ColumnExpr to support the SQL CAST function. Just
because the SQL syntax is the same doesn't mention you should
use invalid sematics. This comes at a slight cost to backwards
compatibility according to the specs:

  Before:
    :x.cast_as(:varchar[20])
  Now:
    :x.cast_as('varchar(20)')

This is actually a good thing, as the before example is an abuse of
the SQL::Function class, when the result is not a function call but a
type specifier.

Add a SQL::IrregularFunction class to handle EXTRACT and CAST.

Add ComplexExpressionMethods#extract, for easily extracting parts
(e.g. month, minute) from dates/times.  Since these parts should
always be numeric, return the result as a NumericExpression.
Delete some file-level RDoc comments, since RDoc stupidly overwrites the Sequel module RDoc with them
Move the ConnectionPool and SingleThreadedPool classes under the Sequel module
Integrate the Validations code into Sequel::Model

Add :decimal fields to the schema parser

Convert numeric fields to BigDecimal in PostgreSQL adapter

The expr argument in join table now allows the same argument as filter, so it can take a string or a blockless filter expression

The following use of join_table now means something different:

  DB[:artists].join_table(:inner, :albums, :artist_id)
  Before:
    => "INNER JOIN albums ON albums.artist_id = artist.id"
  After:
    => "INNER JOIN albums ON artist_id"

Obviously, that is a loss of functionality for that case, but this
commit allows the following cases:

  DB[:artists].join_table(:inner, :albums, "artist_id = artists.id")
  DB[:artists].join_table(:inner, :albums, :number_sold > 1000000)

That's right, you can now use blockless filters, strings, or anything
accepted by filter.

To fix your code that used the previous implementation:

  Change:
    DB[:artists].join_table(:inner, :albums, :artist_id)
  To:
    DB[:artists].join_table(:inner, :albums, :artist_id=>:id)

Coming soon will be the ability for join_table to take a block that
gives the table alias arguments, so you can create blockless filters
that work for arbitrary joins without knowing in advance what table
aliases will be used.
Merge branch 'mybrushbox' into brushboxmerge

pvs: removing support for proc filters in join expressions (since Jeremy is considering deprecating them).
     added support for using an SQL string as the join expression.

Add a :one_to_one option to one_to_many associations, which creates a getter and setter similar to many_to_one (a.k.a. has_one)

The usual use of this is to split one table into multiple tables,
generally either for security or performance reasons.

The getter returns a singular matching record, or raises an error if
multiple records match.

The setter updates the record given and removes associations with all
other records.

The usual many_to_one association methods are either removed if they
are not needed (remove_$, remove_all_$) or made private if they are
($, $_dataset, $_helper, add_$).

Assume that each song has only one lyric and each lyric has only one
song, but the table is split because you don't use the lyrics often
and it performs better to have them in a separate table:

  Song.one_to_many :lyrics, :one_to_one=>true # Note the plural
  song = Song.new(:id => 1)
  song.lyric # <Lyric...>, or nil if no association lyric
  lyric = Lyric.new(:id => 2)
  song.lyric = lyric # UPDATE lyrics SET song_id = 1 WHERE id = 2;
                     # UPDATE lyrics SET song_id = NULL WHERE id != 2
                     #   AND song_id = 1;

Also, this changes the code so that add_ and remove_ for one_to_many
associations call save instead of save! on the object, and raise an
error if the object couldn't be saved.  This was the intent when the
code was originally written.  save! skips validation, it doesn't
raise an error instead of returning false.
Add some missed commits to the sequel_core/CHANGELOG
Rename the Sequel.time_class setting to Sequel.datetime_class
Update CHANGELOGs for recent commits

Raise an error if the :if validation option is not a Symbol, Proc, or nil

Add specs for the :if=>proc{...} case
Merge branch 'mydtsato' into dtsatomerge
Add spec for Model.create_table reloading schema
Merge branch 'myelven' into elvenmerge
bugfix: specifying an alias for a join on a dataset did not work. Added spec and fixed code.
Have Sequel::Migrator RDoc point to the Schema::*Generator
bugfix: specifying an alias for a join on a dataset did not work. Added spec and fixed code.
pvs: adding support for proc {} in join_table expressions.
Bump version to 2.0.1

Have the PostgreSQL and MySQL adapters use the Sequel.time_class setting for datetime/timestamp types

Add a time type to the schema parser, that is used for database time
types (which have time but not date).  There isn't really a ruby
equivalent for this, as the time class holds the date as well, but
continue to use Time when returning and typecasting since it has
been used historical and there isn't a better class in ruby's
standard library.

Have PostgreSQL money type use BigDecimal instead of Float.

Support the PostgreSQL time with time zone type.

Make the choice of Time or DateTime optional for typecasting :datetime types, default to Time

Add Sequel.time_class(=)? methods for getting and setting the time
class used.

Add String#to_sequel_time, which uses Sequel.time_class to convert
the string to the correct time class.

Refactor Database#typecast_value to use the correct time class.

The database adapters need to be converted to call :to_sequel_time
instead of :to_time, but as Time is now the default time class for
:datetime types, there shouldn't be any breakage unless the user
sets Sequel.time_class = DateTime.

Make identifier quoting uppercase by default, to work better with the SQL standard, override in PostgreSQL (Fixes #232)

This should fix the Oracle adapter so it doesn't require
quote_identifiers = false, as well as other adapters that default
unquoted identifiers to uppercase (which is the SQL standard).
Fix syntax error in MySQL adapter complex_expression_sql

Add StringExpression#+, for simple SQL string concatenation

Most simply used like this:

  :x.sql_string + :y # SQL: x || y

This makes SQL string concatenation possible without
Array#sql_string_join.  Unfortunately, the only way to get a
StringExpression is via Array#sql_string_join or
ComplexExpressionMethods#sql_string.  However, if you want
+ to do string concatenation instead of addition by default
for Symbols, include StringConcatenationMethods in Symbol.

Add support for SQL::StringMethods#ilike, for case insensitive pattern matches

ILIKE is a PostgreSQL extension for case insensitive pattern matching,
but some form of it is supported in MySQL and possibly other databases.
Because the blockless filters aren't tied to a particular database,
I have to pick a default syntax and then customize the SQL generated
for each database that supports the same semantics.

Make StringExpression.like take an options hash that supports a
:case_insensitive option, and use this in StringMethods#ilike.

MySQL does case insensitive matches by default for LIKE, so use LIKE
BINARY by default and LIKE instead of ILIKE.  While there, refactor
the pattern match SQL generation and pattern match specs.

SQLite doesn't support regexp matches and does a case insensitive
match (at least for ascii), so have #like and #ilike be identical.
Have SQLite raise an error if a regexp pattern match is attempted.
While there, add pattern specs and refactor and enable the alter
table schema specs that were commented out.

Refactor blockless filter support

Split ComplexExpression functionality into three subclasses:
BooleanExpression, NumericExpression, and StringExpression.  Each
subclass implements certain methods that the other subclasses do not.

BooleanExpression: &, |, ~
NumericExpression: +, -, *, /, <, >, <=, >=
StringExpression: like, <, >, <=, >=

The methods are defined in the BooleanMethods, NumericMethods,
StringMethods, and InequalityMethods modules, which are included
in the above classes as necessary.

All modules are included in the ComplexExpressionMethods module
which is included in LiteralString, Symbol, and SQL::Function.
ComplexExpressionMethods used to be included in SQL::Expression,
but it only really makes sense for SQL::Function, and would
have caused problems if it were included in SQL::Expression,
since ComplexExpression is a subclass of that.

ComplexExpressionMethods also has three new methods: sql_boolean,
sql_number, and sql_string, which return the receiver wrapped
in the appropriate type of expression.  This can be useful if
other libraries overwrite the operators for classes that Sequel
defines the SQL for.  For example, I ran into a situation where
Symbol#/ was defined to make file system path creation easier,
but it returned the result as a string, which Sequel produced
the wrong SQL with (quoting it as a string).  The fix was to
use :symbol.sql_number/10.
Update CHANGELOG for Model.create_table fix
Reload the schema for the table when running Model.create_table
Allowing validation with :if => block

Fix Postgres-Adapter-spec: should correctly parse the schema

The spec is (incorrectly) expecting numerics where there are nils
for datatypes that do not provide a value width.

Add savepoint/nesting support to postgresql transactions

This patch adds SAVEPOINT/ROLLBACK TO/RELEASE support to the
postgresql adapter to implement nested transactions.

To use, simply nest your transactions as you would with other
database adapters:

DB.transaction {
  DB.create_table(:test_table) {
    primary_key :id, :serial
    column :a1, :text
    column :a2, :text
  }
  DB[:test_table].insert(:a1 => 'outer', :a2 => '1')

  DB.transaction {   # autopoint_1
    DB[:test_table].insert(:a1 => 'inner_1', :a2 => '1')

    DB.transaction {   # autopoint_2
      DB[:test_table].insert(:a1 => 'inner_2', :a2 => '1')

      DB.transaction {   # autopoint_3
        DB[:test_table].insert(:a1 => 'inner_3', :a2 => '1')
        raise Sequel::Error::Rollback   # to autopoint_3
      }
    }
  }

  DB[:test_table].insert(:a1 => 'inner_1', :a2 => '2')
}

This will execute the following queries:

BEGIN
CREATE TABLE "test_table" ("id" serial PRIMARY KEY, "a1" text, "a2" text)
INSERT INTO "test_table" ("a2", "a1") VALUES ('1', 'outer')
SAVEPOINT autopoint_1
INSERT INTO "test_table" ("a2", "a1") VALUES ('1', 'inner_1')
SAVEPOINT autopoint_2
INSERT INTO "test_table" ("a2", "a1") VALUES ('1', 'inner_2')
SAVEPOINT autopoint_3
INSERT INTO "test_table" ("a2", "a1") VALUES ('1', 'inner_3')
ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT autopoint_3
RELEASE SAVEPOINT autopoint_2
INSERT INTO "test_table" ("a2", "a1") VALUES ('2', 'inner_1')
RELEASE SAVEPOINT autopoint_1
COMMIT

and will leave you with a table containing:

 id |   a1    | a2
----+---------+----
  1 | outer   | 1
  2 | inner_1 | 1
  3 | inner_2 | 1
	4 | inner_1 | 2
(4 rows)

The chosen implementation will auto-release the current savepoint
as soon as a transaction block ends. This will save some resources
on costly transactions, and not doing so does not yield any other
advantages due to the nature of implementation.

Refactor Inflections support, adding the inflection methods directly to String

Before, the inflection support was convoluted.  The String inflection
methods were in the Inflections module, which was included in String.
Each method in the Inflections module called an Inflector module
method, where Inflector was a module that extended itself.  Inside
Inflector was Inflector::Inflections, a class that included Singleton
and stored the singularization and pluralization rules.

This commit does away with a lot of that crap.  Inflector methods are
now String instance methods, and String::Inflections is a module
that operates as a singleton (similar to Sequel::PrettyTable).

Inflector = String, so if you use Inflector.inflections do..., it will
still work.  You should change that to String.inflections when you have
a chance.

Cache the database schema information by default, add the ability to get the schema for all tables at once

The method schema_for_table is renamed to schema, since it now can get
the schema for all tables in one call. To do so, you call the method
without arguments or with the table_name argument set to nil.  The
2nd argument is now an option hash.  The only option that all adapters
use is :reload, which always grabs fresh information from the database.
MySQL supports a :database option that chooses which database to use,
and PostgreSQL supports a :schema option that chooses which schema to
use.

Most of the private schema methods have been renamed and/or have had
been reworked.

The schema information is cached in the @schemas instance variable in
the database.

Add typecasting on attribute assignment to Sequel::Model objects, optional but enabled by default

For example, if you have a number column of type integer and a title
column of type string:

  Before:
    model.number = '1'
    model.number # => '1'
    model.title = 1
    model.title # => 1
  After:
    model.number = '1'
    model.number # => 1
    model.title = 1
    model.title # => '1'

This builds on the recently added database column reflection support.

Typecasting can be turned off on a global, per class, and per object basis:

  Sequel::Model.typecast_on_assignment = false # Global
  Album.typecast_on_assignment = false # Per Class
  Album.new.typecast_on_assignment = false # Per Object

Note that setting it globally only affects model classes created after
the call, and setting it per class only affects model objects
instantiated after the call.

If the model's dataset uses custom SQL or selects from more than one
table, no typecasting will be used.  If a model only selects specific
columns from a table and uses aliasing, aliased columns won't use
typecasting or potentially will be typecast incorrectly if they use
an alias which is the same as another column name.

You can override the typecasting code by defining your own private
typecast_value(column, value) method for your model class, but remember
to call super if you do.

Inherit parent class's typecast_on_assignment status when subclassing models

OMFG: Add support for blockless filters, lose a little backwards compatibility

The block filters from previous Sequel versions are no longer
necessary, as you now can do pretty much everything with a blockless
filter.  The basics of the block filters are the usual arithmetic,
inequality, and binary operators:

  + = addition
  - = subtraction
  * = multiplication
  / = division
  > = greater than
  < = less than
  >= = greater than or equal to
  <= = less than or equal to
  ~ = negation
  & = AND
  | = OR

You can use these operators on Symbols, LiteralStrings, and other
SQL::Expressions.  Note that there is no equality operator or
inequality operator, to specify equality or inequality, you use a
Hash.

Here are some examples the translation (mostly from the specs):

  # Expression => SQL WHERE clause
  :active => active
  ~:active => NOT active
  ~~:active => active
  ~~~:active => active
  :is_true[] => is_true()
  ~:is_true[] => NOT is_true()
  :x > 100 => (x > 100)
  :x < 100.01 => x < 100.01
  :x <= 0 => (x <= 0)
  :x >= 1 => (x >= 1)
  ~(:x > 100) => (x <= 100)
  {:x => 100} => (x = 100)
  {:x => 'a'} => (x = 'a')
  {:x => nil} => (x IS NULL)
  ~{:x => 100} => (x != 100)
  ~{:x => 'a'} => (x != 'a')
  ~{:x => nil} => (x IS NOT NULL)
  {:x => /a/} => (x ~ 'blah') # Default, MySQL different
  ~{:x => /a/} => (x !~ 'blah') # Default, MySQL different
  :x.like('a') =>  (x LIKE 'a')
  ~:x.like('a') =>  (x NOT LIKE 'a')
  :x.like(/a/) => (x ~ 'a') # Default, MySQL different
  ~:x.like('a', /b/) => ((x NOT LIKE 'a') AND (x !~ 'b')) # Default
  ~{:x => 1..5} => ((x < 1) OR (x > 5))
  ~{:x => DB[:items].select(:i)} => (x NOT IN (SELECT i FROM items))
  ~{:x => [1,2,3]} => (x NOT IN (1, 2, 3))
  :x + 1 > 100 => ((x + 1) > 100)
  (:x * :y) < 100.01 => ((x * y) < 100.01)
  (:x - :y/2) >= 100 => ((x - (y / 2)) >= 100)
  (((:x - :y)/(:x + :y))*:z) <= 100 => ((((x - y) / (x + y)) * z) <= 100)
  ~((((:x - :y)/(:x + :y))*:z) <= 100) => ((((x - y) / (x + y)) * z) > 100)
  :x & :y => (x AND y)
  :x & :y & :z => ((x AND y) AND z)
  :x & {:y => :z} => (x AND (y = z))
  {:y => :z} & :x => ((y = z) AND x)
  {:x => :a} & {:y => :z} => ((x = a) AND (y = z))
  (:x > 200) & (:y < 200) => ((x > 200) AND (y < 200))
  :x | :y => (x OR y)
  :x | :y | :z => ((x OR y) OR z)
  :x | {:y => :z} => (x OR (y = z))
  {:y => :z} | :x => ((y = z) OR x)
  {:x => :a} | {:y => :z} => ((x = a) OR (y = z))
  (:x > 200) | (:y < 200) => ((x > 200) OR (y < 200))
  (:x | :y) & :z => ((x OR y) AND z)
  :x | (:y & :z) => (x OR (y AND z))
  (:x & :w) | (:y & :z) => ((x AND w) OR (y AND z))
  ~((:x | :y) & :z) => ((NOT x AND NOT y) OR NOT z)
  ~((:x & :w) | (:y & :z)) => ((NOT x OR NOT w) AND (NOT y OR NOT z))
  ~((:x > 200) | (:y & :z)) => ((x <= 200) AND (NOT y OR NOT z))
  ~('x'.lit + 1 > 100) => ((x + 1) <= 100)
  'x'.lit.like(/a/) => (x ~ 'a') # (x ~ \'a\')

None of these require blocks, you can use any directly in a call to
filter:

  DB[:items].filter((:price * :tax) - :discount > 100)
  # => SELECT * FROM items WHERE (((price * tax) - discount) > 100)
  DB[:items].filter(:active & ~:archived)
  # => SELECT * FROM items WHERE (active AND NOT archived)

I belive that anything you could previously do in a block filter, you
can now do in a blockless filter using some variation of the
syntax above.

There are some internal changes that were necessary but will cause
some issues.  One is:

  Before:
    Dataset.literal([1,2,3]) => '1, 2, 3'
  After:
    Dataset.literal([1,2,3]) => '(1, 2, 3)'

This makes the implementation agree with the RDoc, which stated that
.literal should surround arrays with parantheses.  Unfortunately, it
also means that you need to change the following:

  Before:
    Dataset.filter('a IN (?)', [1,2,3]) => 'a in (1, 2, 3)'
  After:
    Dataset.filter('a IN ?', [1,2,3]) => 'a in (1, 2, 3)'
    Dataset.filter('a IN (?)', [1,2,3]) => 'a in ((1, 2, 3))' # !!!

There is some other fallout from this.  One thing is that
certain methods that were more forgiving in their accepted arguments
are no longer as forgiving.  For example, .order and .select will
not longer work correctly when passed an array directly.  You now
need to pass the arguments individually, with is as easy as *:

  Before:
    cols = [:a, :b]
    DB[:items].order(cols).select(cols) => 'ORDER BY a, b'
  After:
    cols = [:a, :b]
    DB[:items].order(*cols).select(*cols) => 'ORDER BY a, b'
    DB[:items].order(cols).select(cols) => 'ORDER BY (a, b)' # !!!

There might be some breakage in the adapters, due to the internal
changes.  I looked through all adapters and made changes if I thought
they were necessary, but I might not have caught everything.  I
tested SQLite, PostgreSQL, and MySQL, and all specs pass.  This could
really use more thorough testing, and the best way to get that is to
commit it.

Another major internal change is that the filter dataset options,
:where and :having, now store not an SQL fragment, but an object
that when literalized will be an SQL fragment (generally either
a Sequel::LiteralString or a Sequel::SQL::ComplexExpression).

Some Dataset private instance methods have been deleted
(expression_list, expression_list_map), and some methods that are now
just used by the block filters are now in parse_tree_sequelizer, so
they aren't loaded if parse_tree is not present.

Some other small output is a change in how many parantheses are used
and where they show up, but there shouldn't be any functional
changes to existing filters.  Mainly that will complicate testing
if you are checking for specific SQL.

I'm also removing all the default spec options.  I find they hurt
much more than they help.

Major update to the postgres adapter, mostly from jdavis with changes by me (Fixes #225)

This patch:
 * adds support for the "pg" module from the ruby-pg project at
   - http://rubyforge.org/projects/ruby-pg
   - gem install pg
   - favors 'pg' module, and falls back to 'postgres' module
 * before it only worked on postgresql 8.2 and above. Now it works on
   postgresql 7.3 through 8.3.
 * refactored as inheritance rather than monkeypatching the PGconn class
 * fix some SQL in SELECT_PK_AND_CUSTOM_SEQUENCE in the same way I fixed it
   for the AR adapter (see: http://dev.rubyonrails.org/ticket/11127)
 * no longer monkeypatch class String
 * removed array_tuples_fetch_rows and related methods.
 * override quote method, rather than conditionally redefining it in terms
   of itself
 * remove async_exec() calls, because they lead to nondeterministic results
   (errors about commands already in progress) involving the connection pool.
 * handle converter methods as lambda functions and don't eval() anything.
   The old design was extremely complex.
 * use simpler, more basic driver functionality to enable proper support
   for all postgresql drivers. For example, I use PGresult#getvalue instead of
   relying on a record being an array, or a hash indexed by symbol, or a hash
   indexed by string.
 * disable auto translation for drivers that support it. This just added
   another layer of complexity since Sequel can do it anyway.

MAJOR changes: Make identifier quoting optional, quote all identifiers, force explicit table aliasing when joining

Quoting identifiers (tables and columns) is now optional.  Quoting
identifiers is usually not needed unless you have identifiers that:

  1) have embedded spaces (e.g. "column name"), or
  2) overlap with SQL keywords (e.g. "select"), or
  3) are case sensitive (e.g. "ColumnName" and "columnName")

If you have identifiers that require identifier quoting, you should turn
it on.  You can do so on a global level, per-database level, and/or
per-dataset level:

  Global:
    Sequel.quote_identifiers = true
    Sequel::Database.quote_identifiers = true
  Per Database:
    DB = Sequel.connect(..., :quote_identifiers=>true)
    DB.quote_identifiers = true
  Per Dataset
    Sequel.sqlite[:table].quote_identifiers = true

Quoting identifiers now includes tables, not just columns like before.
If you have tests with check for specific SQL and you were using a
database except MySQL, PostgreSQL, or SQLite, they are probably broken.
To fix them, you should either stop quoting the columns (if you don't
need quoted identifiers), or start quoting the tables (if you need
quoted identifiers).

The default quoting is now the double quote, instead of no quoting at
all.  However, quoting identifiers is off by default.  Previously, only
three adapters supported quoting.  Now, all adapters should support it,
assuming they use the standard SQL double quote.

join_table now takes an optional extra argument, a table alias.  IF you
need an aliased table, you MUST change your code:

  Before:
    DB[:artist].join_table(:inner, "albums a", :artist_id=>:id)
  After:
    DB[:artist].join_table(:inner, :albums, {:artist_id=>:id}, :a)

  Before:
    DB[:artist].left_outer_join("albums a", :artist_id=>:id)
  After:
    DB[:artist].left_outer_join(:albums, {:artist_id=>:id}, :a)

If you don't do this, you WILL end up with invalid SQL.  I try to
prevent these kinds of issues, but in this case the design was so bad it
had to be changed.  Before, Sequel was parsing the given table and
column with a regular expression, which simply cannot be done reliably.
It makes much more sense to provide an explicit table alias if it is
needed.

Here are some other small fallout issues from the change:

Due to some refactoring, the private Dataset#join_expr method has been
merged into Dataset#join_table.

Dataset#quote_column_ref is now an alias to quote_identifier, which will
optionally quote the given identifier if identifier quoting is enabled.

To override the default SQL quoting for an adapter, define a
quoted_identifier method for that adapter's dataset, that returns a
quoted version of the identifier.  See the MySQL and SQLite adapters for
an example.

Dataset::ALIASED_REGEXP and Dataset::QUALIFIED_REGEXP have been
eliminated.

You can now use embedded spaces inside symbols and have the qualifying
and/or aliasing work.  Of course, if you do this, you should have
identifier quoting turned on.  Examples:

  :"Table Name__Column Name"
  :"Table Name__Column Name___Alias Name"
  :"Column Name___Alias Name"

Dataset#to_table_reference is now a protected method.  Instead of taking
an optional index number and creating an table alias based on it, it now
takes an optional table alias.  Also, it now always gives a subselect
instead of a simple table name even if the dataset just has a single
:from option with a single table.

Dataset#symbol_to_column_ref now takes an optional second argument
specifying a table name to use if a column isn't qualified.  If a table
name is given, it returns an Sequel::SQL::QualifiedColumnRef instead of
a string.

arguments.  If you pass a block and an integer argument, you get an array of
records filtered by the block and limited to the integer given. If you pass
a block and a non-integer argument(s), both the block and the arguments are
used to filter the records.

first with no arguments still returns a single record.

Last now just calls reverse and then first with the block and arguments it
was given, so it's much more powerful now.

Add the :join_type, :graph_conditions, and :graph_join_conditions association options, used when eager graphing

Here's some examples from the specs:

join_type:

  GraphAlbum.many_to_one :inner_band, :class=>'GraphBand', :key=>:band_id, :join_type=>:inner
  GraphAlbum.eager_graph(:inner_band).sql
  => 'SELECT albums.id, albums.band_id, inner_band.id AS inner_band_id, inner_band.vocalist_id FROM albums INNER JOIN bands inner_band ON (inner_band.id = albums.band_id)'

:graph_conditions

  GraphAlbum.many_to_one :active_band, :class=>'GraphBand', :key=>:band_id, :graph_conditions=>{:active=>true}
  GraphAlbum.eager_graph(:active_band).sql
  => "SELECT albums.id, albums.band_id, active_band.id AS active_band_id, active_band.vocalist_id FROM albums LEFT OUTER JOIN bands active_band ON (active_band.id = albums.band_id) AND (active_band.active = 't')"

:graph_join_conditions (many_to_many associations only)

  GraphAlbum.many_to_many :active_genres, :class=>'GraphGenre', :left_key=>:album_id, :right_key=>:genre_id, :join_table=>:ag, :graph_join_conditions=>{:active=>true}
  GraphAlbum.eager_graph(:active_genres).sql
  => "SELECT albums.id, albums.band_id, active_genres.id AS active_genres_id FROM albums LEFT OUTER JOIN ag ON (ag.album_id = albums.id) AND (ag.active = 't') LEFT OUTER JOIN genres active_genres ON (active_genres.id = ag.genre_id)"

Naturally, all options can be used simultaneously.

Allow an array of arrays instead of a hash when specifying conditions

This was previously not allowed, as the code assumed the array was in the
[string, param1, param2, ...] format.  The code now handles an array the same
as before if the first element is a string, and treats it like a hash if not.

The need for this is to be able to specify multiple conditions on the same
column in the joined table when doing a join.  Previously, this was impossible,
as the code needed a hash and specifying multiple conditions would use the same
hash key, so one of the conditions would be ignored.

A side benefit to this is that you can have more predictable specs because
the array of arrays will always give the conditions in the same order in the
resulting SQL.

Change hook methods so that if a tag/method is specified it overwrites an existing hook block with the same tag/method

Assume:

  class Artist < Sequel::Model
    def do_stuff
      ...
    end
    before_save :do_stuff
    before_save :do_stuff
  end

Before:

  Artist.new.save # do_stuff called twice!

After:

  Artist.new.save # do_stuff called once

It's unlikely you would do the above in real code, but if you have
an application that does automatic reloading of source (such as
Ramaze), this will prevent it adding to the hooks everytime it
reloads the source file.

Note that you can add tags with blocks, to prevent the reloading:

  class Artist < Sequel::Model
    before_save(:do_stuff){...}
  end

If you use both tags and methods with the same name, the last
one wins.

tags/methods are stored per model, so this works the way you
expect:

  class Artist < Sequel::Model
    before_save(:do_stuff){...}
  end
  class BigArtist < Artist
    before_save(:do_stuff){...}
  end
  BigArtist.new.save # calls both the Artist and BigArtist blocks
