Bump version to 1.5.1

Have Dataset#graph give a nil value instead of a hash with all nil values if no matching rows exist in the graphed table

Before:

  # If the first artist doesn't have any albums
  DB[:artists].graph(:albums, :artist_id=>:id).first
  => {:artists=>{:id=>artists.id, :name=>artists.name}, :albums=>{:id=>nil, :name=>nil, :artist_id=>nil}}

After:

  # If the first artist doesn't have any albums
  DB[:artists].graph(:albums, :artist_id=>:id).first
  => {:artists=>{:id=>artists.id, :name=>artists.name}, :albums=>nil}

This also fixes eager_graph, so that you don't end up with a single empty associated object in
*_to_many associations (that is shared by all objects without an associated record in the database).

Before:

  # If the first two artists don't have any albums
  Artist.eager_graph(:albums).all.first.albums
  => [#<Album @values={:id=>nil, :name=>nil, :artist_id=>nil}>]
  Artist.eager_graph(:albums).all[0].albums.first.object_id == \
   Artist.eager_graph(:albums).all[1].albums.first.object_id
  => true

After:

  # If the first two artists don't have any albums
  Artist.eager_graph(:albums).all[0].albums
  => []
  Artist.eager_graph(:albums).all[1].albums
  => []

This also fixes eager_graph for many_to_one associations, in that if the associated record doesn't
exist, an empty (and again, shared) item is not used.

Before:

  # If the first two albums don't have an artist
  Album.eager_graph(:artists).all.first.artist
  => [#<Artist @values={:id=>nil, :name=>nil}>]
  Album.eager_graph(:artists).all[0].artist.object_id == \
   Album.eager_graph(:artists).all[1].artist.object_id
  => true

After:

  # If the first two albums don't have an artist
  Album.eager_graph(:artists).all[0].artist
  => nil
  Album.eager_graph(:artists).all[1].artist
  => nil

Use reciprocal associations for all types of associations in the getter/setter/add_/remove_ methods

If "Album.many_to_one :band" and "Band.one_to_many :albums":

  # many_to_one setter adds to reciprocal association
  band1.albums # => []
  album1.band = band1
  band1.albums # => [album1]
  band2.albums # => []
  album1.band = band2
  band1.albums # => []
  band2.albums # => [album1]
  album1.band = band2
  band2.albums # => [album1]
  album1.band = nil
  band2.albums # => []

  # one_to_many add_* method sets reciprocal association
  # one_to_many remove_* method removes reciprocal association
  album1.band # => nil
  band1.add_album(album1)
  album1.band # => band1
  band2.add_album(album1)
  album1.band # => band2
  band2.remove_album(album1)
  album1.band # => nil

If "Post.many_to_many :tags" and "Tag.many_to_many :posts"

  # many_to_many add_* method adds to reciprocal association
  # many_to_many remove_* method removes from reciprocal association
  post1.tags # => []
  tag1.posts # => []
  tag1.add_post(post1)
  post1.tags # => [tag1]
  tag1.posts # => [post1]
  tag1.remove_post(post1)
  post1.tags # => []
  tag1.posts # => []
  post1.add_tag(tag1)
  post1.tags # => [tag1]
  tag1.posts # => [post1]
  post1.remove_tag(tag1)
  post1.tags # => []
  tag1.posts # => []

The code is fairly intelligent about finding the reciprocal association, but
if you have more than one association with the same class and key(s), you may
have to set the reciprocal option in association ":reciprocal=>:@ivname", where
ivname is the name of the reciprocal association.  If you want to disable the
use of reciprocals for the association, use :reciprocal=>nil.

Setup deprecation structure, deprecate Dataset#method_missing

Deprecation structure is flexible, you can choose a where the deprecation messages get sent:

  Sequel::Deprecation.deprecation_message_stream = STDERR # the default
  Sequel::Deprecation.deprecation_message_stream = File.new('deprecation.txt', 'wb') # A file
  Sequel::Deprecation.deprecation_message_stream = nil # no deprecation messages!

Here's what the messages look like:

  filter! is not a defined method. filter! is deprecated, and will be removed in Sequel 2.0.
  order_by_name is not a defined_method, please use order(:name). order_by_name is deprecated, and will be removed in Sequel 2.0.

You can turn on tracebacks for deprecated methods, so you can see where exactly you need to fix your code:

  Sequel::Deprecation.print_tracebacks = true

Here's what the tracebacks look like:

  ./spec/../lib/sequel_core/deprecated.rb:19:in `deprecate'
  ./spec/../lib/sequel_core/deprecated.rb:49:in `last_by_name'
  ./spec/dataset_spec.rb:2717
  /usr/local/lib/ruby/gems/1.8/gems/rspec-1.1.3/lib/spec/example/example_methods.rb:78:in `instance_eval'
  /usr/local/lib/ruby/gems/1.8/gems/rspec-1.1.3/lib/spec/example/example_methods.rb:78:in `run_with_description_capturing'
  ...

With good test coverage and the print_tracebacks feature, getting your code ready for Sequel 2.0 should be a breeze.

name: perl-authen-sasl
description: Perl library for performing SASL authentication

commit.message:
Makes sure that user callbacks are called

Even for dumb mechanisms like LOGIN and PLAIN

Merge remote branch 'gbarr/master'

resolving version and build conflicts(?)

Conflicts:
	Makefile.PL
	lib/Authen/SASL.pm
	lib/Authen/SASL/Perl/DIGEST_MD5.pm
Release 2.14
update .gitignore

Skip tests requiring Crypt::*

This fixes a problem with the test suite failing on some system

Skip tests requiring Crypt::*

This fixes a problem with the test suite failing on some system

Transformed server_start and server_step to use callbacks
allowing me to execute SASL negotiations fully asynchronously within
djabberd.

Tests are still expecting a linear run

set_success really returns the status, there is no need
to return 1 for PLAIN authentication, otherwise this is
sent to the client which confuses some implementations.

removed the SQOP global variable hack that I used in tests
to change qop for the server

revised server_new and the options that can be passed to it
takes a hash with no_integrity and no_confidentiality configurations.

Trying different logic for LOGIN in the client.
I'm still not sure about this change.
I'm also pondering about renaming set_success to something less ambiguous.
We might need better semantic in the client, where success of a negotiation
is communicated to the client thru specific protocol means sometimes.

I think this fixes a bug that always enable auth-conf when
the system doesn't support it and vice-versa
No ambiguity with licensing
Added server LOGIN support for fun
typo 'response' and not 'challenge'
Added effective support for checkpass callback in PLAIN

Trying to be a bit more compatible with the future Authen::SASL::XS
It has to be noted that getsecret is a deprecated callback in SASL v2
(apparently).

Helped MakeMaker finding my new tests
Fixed tests issues
test for nonce-count check (replay attacks)

- Added maxbuf to the challenge (we should probably omit it when auth
  is proposed only, but that should be fine)
- Fixed an issue (I believe) where the client was looking for 'server-maxbuf'
  insted of 'maxbuf'

Created top level imports for all frameworks. This change broke backwards compatibility for YUI, where users should now @import yui.sass instead of yui/screen.sass
extracted a +global-reset and +nested-reset mixins from the reset library which got moved to compass/utilities/general/reset.

On second thought: Don't scope blueprint grid classes within the container. This will make them difficult to override and BP-css doesn't do it.
Updated the manifest and gemspec.

Coding spree to clean up the blueprint stylesheets and make them more similar to blueprint-css, more configurable, and more consistent.

Breakdown of changes:

===

Remove the body scope that is unnecessarily added to many blueprint classes due to the way the mixins were constructed and used. Blueprint mixins that operate on the body tag now follow a pattern where they take the body selector as an argument and must always be mixed into the top level of a stylesheet. The classes will be scoped whenever the selector is not a simple "body" selector which is the default. Mixins affected: +blueprint-ie, +blueprint-print, +blueprint-typography, and +blueprint-scaffolding. All of these mixins use corresponding +[mixin]-body and +[mixin]-defaults mixins in their implementations that you can use directly if you feel constrained by the requirement to mix into the top-level.

===

Made all configurable constants possible to override in a base stylesheet using conditional assignment. Moved many colors that were still hard coded to the colors.sass module so they can be overridden.

===

Restored some blueprint defaults even though I didn't like them. With the exception of the blueprint link urls which are now available as a mixin called +blueprint-show-link-urls (they used to just be commented out.)

===

Grid constants have been renamed in both the grid and liquid grid modules. These constants are now conditionally assigned to make the grid easily configured.

===

The liquid grid now uses the compass clearfix.

===

moved the primary mixin for a module (where one exists) to the top of the file for clarity of readers.

===

blueprint grid classes are now appropriately scoped under the .container class.
The Liquid grid mixin has been renamed from +blueprint-liquid to +blueprint-liquid-grid.

The incremental leading mixin (+incr) in the fancy type module now accepts arguments and performs the incremental leading calculations for you if you want to use different font sizes. The +dquo mixin now accepts an offset argument if the default isn't appropriate.
The no-print and print-only classes were never part of blueprint-css, so I'm moving them to compass utilities.
test blueprint typography output.
Changes to blueprint mixins so that they can be mixed into the top level and avoid having scoped selectors that add to their weight.
Updated gemspec and version to 0.1.1
Updated the manifest and gemspec.
Added unit tests for YUI and did some cleanup/restructuring of the test fixtures as well as a way to validate generated css.

Fixed the --imports command-line option so that it generates useful output for being passed to sass. E.g.:

sass `compass --imports` some_file.sass
Updated manifest and gemspec.
Renamed the yui examples folder.
Started working on a YUI Grid Subdivisions example.
Renamed utilities haml file to follow new naming scheme.
Update manifest and gemspec with new files.
Allow the blueprint font family defaults to be configured.
Updated the YUI Examples.
Fixed a duplicate ending bug in the examples generator.
Updated the README.
Move the #ft and #bd declarations to the the yui-grids-init mixin and allow those styles to be turned off.
Extract the yui-grid-templates mixin for clarity.
Combine the selectors that have the same styles that I previously separated unecessarily.
Use a ruby formatted gemspec instead of yaml. Maybe github will like it better.
Updated the Gem Manifest.
Added conditional assignment to the yui constants and prefixed them with "yui_".
Added the YUI grids module. It compiles and generates roughly the expected output, but is not well tested yet.

Added a Sass Function called nest that performs a nesting operation on (possibly) comma delimited selectors and emits the result as a string.
For example:

nest(".foo", "a, em, b")

would render:

.foo a, .foo em, .foo b

The nest function can take any number of arguments and each argument can have any number of comma-delimited selectors.
- added missing entries to cover 'lib/compass/commands/watch_project.rb'
Added a compass command-line option to watch a project and automatically recompile when it changes. Use compass --watch.
Reuse the reset and clearfix mixins in the horizontal-list declaration.
Allow the padding between the list items in horizontal-list mixin to be specified as an argument.
Generate less CSS output for the same effect in the reset.
Removed some erroneous entries in the Manifest file and changed the rakefile so they wouldn't happen again.
Added a gemspec and updated the Manifest.
Improvements to the YUI fonts. These changes are not backwards compatible.
A cross-browser inline-block mixin that supports ie6-8, ff2-3, opera, and webkit.
Command line option to emit the compass import paths suitable for use in a PATH variable.
Fixed a bug in the definition of push. The left margin was incorrect.
Small changes to accomodate Sass language advancements. Negation is now 'not' and @else exists.
Fixed duplicate directory information in the rails initializer generator.
Slighltly cleaner horizontal-list implementation.
Factor out a reset-box-model mixin for doing selective resets.
clearfix for firefox works better with overflow: -moz-scrollbars-none

Added a basic test case. So far it can be used to make sure your stylesheets compile.
Eventually it should provide assertions for generated rules and styles.
Incorrect framework nesting in the compass initializers. The frameworks scope themselves.
Don't set background properties that aren't relevant to the text replacement.
Don't set display for replaced text -- just use the container's default display. Also, some small refactoring.
Changes to the liquid example for the new reset.
Background is not a typography concern, removed from normal-text mixin.
Introduced replace-text mixin for showing images in place of HTML text.

Backward Incompatible Change: Removed unnecessary html/body scoping for reset rules and made reset.sass a standalone stylesheet.

To perform a reset, simply @import compass/reset.sass

To perform a selective reset, you should @import compass/utilities/general/reset.sass which will provide
reset mixins without defining any css rules.
Small changes to liquid.sass from code review.

The example can be found at examples/blueprint_semantic/parts/liquid.html

Add SASS adaptation of liquid.css.
Liquid.css is a liquid adaptation of the Blueprint grid by Ben Listwon, David Bedingfield and Andrei Michael Herasimchuk at Involution Studios.
Fixed some broken relative imports.
Fixed a double slash and use File::SEPARATOR instead of slash for portability.
Use explicit sass imports to get better error reporting in the case of a missing file or installation problem.
remove gemspec, it's a generated file.
Use the compass link-colors mixin on blueprint.
Updated the gem manifest.
Added a compass example page that demonstrates the various utility mixins

Sass Utility Mixins that encapsulate many common styling patterns. Using them can significantly speed up the styling of a webpage.

Here's a quick rundown of what's included in this checkin (@ denotes an import file, + denotes a mixin):

@ compass/utilities
  @ compass/utilities/general
    @ compass/utilities/general/clearfix
      +clearfix - Clearing floats without extra markup
    @ compass/utilities/general/tag_cloud
      +tag-cloud(!base_size = 1em) - Emits styles for a tag cloud
  @ compass/utilities/links
    @ compass/utilities/links/hover_link
      +hover-link - makes a link underlined only when hovered.
    @ compass/utilities/links/link_colors
      +link-colors(!normal, [!hover, !active, !visited, !focus]) - specify all the colors
        of a link with one mixin. Colors not sepecified will not be emitted, this may or
        may not work out depending on how you've defined your style rules.
    @ compass/utilities/links/unstyled_link
      +unstyled-link - A link that looks and acts like the text it is contained within
  @ compass/utilities/lists
    @ compass/utilities/lists/bullets
      +no-bullet - Turns off the bullet for a single list element.
      +no-bullets - Turns off the bullets for all the list elements in a list.
      +pretty-bullets(!bullet_icon, !width, !height[, !line_height = 18px, !padding = 14px]) - use an icon for the list elements of a list.
    @ compass/utilities/lists/horizontal_list
      +horizontal-list - A list where the elements are floated left.
    @ compass/utilities/lists/inline_list
      +inline-list - A list where both the list and the list elements are inlined.
      +comma-delimited-list - an inline-list that is comma delimited.
  @ compass/utilities/tables
    @ compass/utilities/tables/alternating_rows_and_columns
      +alternating-rows-and-columns(!even_row_color, !odd_row_color, !dark_intersection) - The first colors are the even/odd colors respectively and the last argument is a shade that is subtracted from those colors for the even columns.
  @ compass/utilities/text
    @ compass/utilities/text/nowrap
      +nowrap - Because remembering whether or not there's a hyphen in white-space is too hard
